# Agent Instructions

This project uses **bd** (beads) for issue tracking. Run `bd onboard` to get started.

## Quick Reference

```bash
bd ready              # Find available work
bd show <id>          # View issue details
bd update <id> --status in_progress  # Claim work
bd close <id>         # Complete work
bd sync               # Sync with git
```

## Landing the Plane (Session Completion)

**When ending a work session**, you MUST complete ALL steps below. Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds.

**MANDATORY WORKFLOW:**

1. **File issues for remaining work** - Create issues for anything that needs follow-up
2. **Run quality gates** (if code changed) - Tests, linters, builds
3. **Update issue status** - Close finished work, update in-progress items
4. **PUSH TO REMOTE** - This is MANDATORY:
   ```bash
   git pull --rebase
   bd sync
   git push
   git status  # MUST show "up to date with origin"
   ```
5. **Clean up** - Clear stashes, prune remote branches
6. **Verify** - All changes committed AND pushed
7. **Hand off** - Provide context for next session

**CRITICAL RULES:**
- Work is NOT complete until `git push` succeeds
- NEVER stop before pushing - that leaves work stranded locally
- NEVER say "ready to push when you are" - YOU must push
- If push fails, resolve and retry until it succeeds

file.content:
## 1. Solidity Contract Setup

- [ ] 1.1 Scaffold `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/` with Hardhat (hardhat.config.ts, package.json, tsconfig)
- [ ] 1.2 Install Hardhat dependencies (`hardhat`, `@nomicfoundation/hardhat-toolbox`, `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat`)
- [ ] 1.3 Write `contracts/FdcAccounting.sol` per the sapphire-accounting spec (creditDeposit, getBalance, getBalanceOf, onlyRelayer, double-credit prevention, zero-value rejection)
- [ ] 1.4 Compile the contract and verify clean build with `npx hardhat compile`

## 2. Relayer TypeScript Setup

- [ ] 2.1 Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime` dependency to root package.json
- [ ] 2.2 Create `fdc-trusted-relayer/src/accounting-demo.ts` with provider initialization (Coston2 standard provider, Sapphire wrapped provider)
- [ ] 2.3 Add contract ABI/bytecode import from Hardhat artifacts into the TypeScript relayer

## 3. Contract Deployment Logic

- [ ] 3.1 Implement deploy-or-connect logic: deploy `FdcAccounting` if no address in env, otherwise attach to existing
- [ ] 3.2 Set `authorizedRelayer` to the signer's address on fresh deploy

## 4. FDC Attestation & Verification

- [ ] 4.1 Implement (or import from poc.ts) the FDC attestation flow: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof
- [ ] 4.2 Implement on-chain proof verification via `FdcVerification` view call on Coston2
- [ ] 4.3 Abort relay if proof verification returns false

## 5. Relay to Sapphire

- [ ] 5.1 Extract `sourceAddress`, `value`, and `transactionHash` from verified proof response body
- [ ] 5.2 Call `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` on the Sapphire accounting contract
- [ ] 5.3 Query and log the depositor's balance via `getBalanceOf` after crediting

## 6. Configuration & Wiring

- [ ] 6.1 Update `.env.example` with new vars: `SAPPHIRE_RPC`, `SAPPHIRE_PK`, `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` (optional)
- [ ] 6.2 Add npm script to run the accounting demo (`npm run accounting-demo` or similar)
- [ ] 6.3 Verify full end-to-end flow: deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí query balance

content.content:
1‚Üí## Context
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThe existing `src/poc.ts` demonstrates FDC attestation end-to-end: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof, verify on-chain. This design extends that flow to relay verified deposit data to a Sapphire accounting contract, mirroring FlexVaults' architecture with dramatically less infrastructure.
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe codebase uses TypeScript (strict ESM), ethers.js v6, and runs via tsx. There are no existing Solidity contracts or Hardhat tooling in the project.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Goals / Non-Goals
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí**Goals:**
    10‚Üí- Demonstrate FDC-verified cross-chain deposit accounting on Sapphire with private balances
    11‚Üí- Keep the relayer simple ‚Äî single TypeScript entry point, no queue or persistence
    12‚Üí- Reuse existing FDC attestation logic from `src/poc.ts` where possible
    13‚Üí- Provide a self-contained demo that deploys the contract and runs the full flow
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí**Non-Goals:**
    16‚Üí- Production relayer (no retries, no event watching, no queue)
    17‚Üí- ROFL TEE integration for the relayer (plain EOA signer for PoC)
    18‚Üí- ERC-20 token support (native ETH only)
    19‚Üí- Withdrawals, transfers, or fund locking
    20‚Üí- Mainnet deployment or gas optimization
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí## Decisions
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí### 1. Separate `contracts/` subdirectory with Hardhat
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí**Decision**: Solidity compilation via Hardhat in `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/`, separate from the tsx-based TypeScript runtime.
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí**Rationale**: Hardhat handles Solidity compilation, ABI generation, and deployment scripts cleanly. Keeping it in a subdirectory avoids polluting the root `package.json` with Solidity tooling.
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Inline ABI as a JSON constant in TypeScript. Rejected because it makes the contract source non-compilable and harder to verify/modify.
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí### 2. Single-file relayer at `src/accounting-demo.ts`
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí**Decision**: One TypeScript file orchestrates the full flow (deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí relay ‚Üí query).
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí**Rationale**: Matches the project's existing pattern (`src/poc.ts` is single-file). For a PoC, a linear script is clearer than a modular architecture.
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Extract shared FDC logic into a library module. Worth doing if the codebase grows, but premature for two files.
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### 3. Sapphire provider wrapping with `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime`
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí**Decision**: Wrap the ethers.js provider with `sapphire.wrap()` for automatic transaction encryption.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**Rationale**: This is the standard Sapphire integration pattern. It encrypts calldata so balance queries and deposits stay confidential on-chain.
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí### 4. Contract deploys fresh each run (no address persistence)
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí**Decision**: The demo script deploys `FdcAccounting` on each run rather than persisting a contract address.
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí**Rationale**: Simplifies the PoC ‚Äî no state file or env var management for contract addresses. The demo is self-contained. Users can easily modify to connect to an existing deployment.
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí### 5. Double-credit prevention via tx hash mapping
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí**Decision**: `processedTxHashes` mapping in the contract prevents the same Sepolia tx from being credited twice.
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí**Rationale**: Essential correctness property. Even though the PoC relayer only runs once, the contract must be safe against replays for any real usage.
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí## Risks / Trade-offs
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí- **[Trusted relayer is a single point of trust]** ‚Üí Acceptable for PoC. In production, wrap in ROFL TEE or use multisig. The contract's `onlyRelayer` modifier is already designed for a single authorized address, which maps cleanly to a ROFL app address.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí- **[FDC proof verified on Coston2, not on Sapphire]** ‚Üí The relayer bridges two separate chains. The Sapphire contract trusts the relayer's attestation. This is architecturally identical to FlexVaults (ROFL backend verifies proof, then writes to Sapphire).
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí- **[Sapphire testnet availability]** ‚Üí Sapphire testnet may have downtime. No mitigation needed for a PoC.
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí- **[Hardhat adds dependency weight]** ‚Üí Only needed in `contracts/` subdirectory. Does not affect the tsx runtime. Could use solc directly but Hardhat provides better DX for deployment.
    67‚Üí

file.content:
## Context

The existing `src/poc.ts` demonstrates FDC attestation end-to-end: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof, verify on-chain. This design extends that flow to relay verified deposit data to a Sapphire accounting contract, mirroring FlexVaults' architecture with dramatically less infrastructure.

The codebase uses TypeScript (strict ESM), ethers.js v6, and runs via tsx. There are no existing Solidity contracts or Hardhat tooling in the project.

## Goals / Non-Goals

**Goals:**
- Demonstrate FDC-verified cross-chain deposit accounting on Sapphire with private balances
- Keep the relayer simple ‚Äî single TypeScript entry point, no queue or persistence
- Reuse existing FDC attestation logic from `src/poc.ts` where possible
- Provide a self-contained demo that deploys the contract and runs the full flow

**Non-Goals:**
- Production relayer (no retries, no event watching, no queue)
- ROFL TEE integration for the relayer (plain EOA signer for PoC)
- ERC-20 token support (native ETH only)
- Withdrawals, transfers, or fund locking
- Mainnet deployment or gas optimization

## Decisions

### 1. Separate `contracts/` subdirectory with Hardhat

**Decision**: Solidity compilation via Hardhat in `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/`, separate from the tsx-based TypeScript runtime.

**Rationale**: Hardhat handles Solidity compilation, ABI generation, and deployment scripts cleanly. Keeping it in a subdirectory avoids polluting the root `package.json` with Solidity tooling.

**Alternative considered**: Inline ABI as a JSON constant in TypeScript. Rejected because it makes the contract source non-compilable and harder to verify/modify.

### 2. Single-file relayer at `src/accounting-demo.ts`

**Decision**: One TypeScript file orchestrates the full flow (deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí relay ‚Üí query).

**Rationale**: Matches the project's existing pattern (`src/poc.ts` is single-file). For a PoC, a linear script is clearer than a modular architecture.

**Alternative considered**: Extract shared FDC logic into a library module. Worth doing if the codebase grows, but premature for two files.

### 3. Sapphire provider wrapping with `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime`

**Decision**: Wrap the ethers.js provider with `sapphire.wrap()` for automatic transaction encryption.

**Rationale**: This is the standard Sapphire integration pattern. It encrypts calldata so balance queries and deposits stay confidential on-chain.

### 4. Contract deploys fresh each run (no address persistence)

**Decision**: The demo script deploys `FdcAccounting` on each run rather than persisting a contract address.

**Rationale**: Simplifies the PoC ‚Äî no state file or env var management for contract addresses. The demo is self-contained. Users can easily modify to connect to an existing deployment.

### 5. Double-credit prevention via tx hash mapping

**Decision**: `processedTxHashes` mapping in the contract prevents the same Sepolia tx from being credited twice.

**Rationale**: Essential correctness property. Even though the PoC relayer only runs once, the contract must be safe against replays for any real usage.

## Risks / Trade-offs

- **[Trusted relayer is a single point of trust]** ‚Üí Acceptable for PoC. In production, wrap in ROFL TEE or use multisig. The contract's `onlyRelayer` modifier is already designed for a single authorized address, which maps cleanly to a ROFL app address.

- **[FDC proof verified on Coston2, not on Sapphire]** ‚Üí The relayer bridges two separate chains. The Sapphire contract trusts the relayer's attestation. This is architecturally identical to FlexVaults (ROFL backend verifies proof, then writes to Sapphire).

- **[Sapphire testnet availability]** ‚Üí Sapphire testnet may have downtime. No mitigation needed for a PoC.

- **[Hardhat adds dependency weight]** ‚Üí Only needed in `contracts/` subdirectory. Does not affect the tsx runtime. Could use solc directly but Hardhat provides better DX for deployment.

content.content:
1‚Üí## ADDED Requirements
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí### Requirement: Authorized relayer credit
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe `FdcAccounting` contract SHALL accept deposit credits only from the authorized relayer address set at construction time. Any call to `creditDeposit` from a non-relayer address MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer credits a deposit
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` with a valid tx hash, depositor address, and non-zero value
    10‚Üí- **THEN** the contract records the deposit, increments the depositor's balance by `value`, and emits `DepositCredited(depositor, value, txHash)`
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí#### Scenario: Non-relayer attempts credit
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí- **WHEN** any address other than the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit`
    15‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí### Requirement: Double-credit prevention
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíThe contract SHALL track processed Sepolia transaction hashes and reject any attempt to credit the same tx hash twice.
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí#### Scenario: First credit for a tx hash
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has not been processed before
    24‚Üí- **THEN** the deposit is credited and the tx hash is marked as processed
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí#### Scenario: Duplicate credit attempt
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has already been processed
    29‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `AlreadyProcessed(txHash)`
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí### Requirement: Zero-value rejection
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThe contract SHALL reject deposits with zero value to prevent meaningless state changes.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí#### Scenario: Zero-value deposit
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with `value = 0`
    38‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `ZeroValue()`
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### Requirement: Private balance storage
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíDepositor balances SHALL be stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private mapping). Balances MUST NOT be readable by arbitrary external observers.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí#### Scenario: Depositor queries own balance
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí- **WHEN** a depositor calls `getBalance()` from their own address
    47‚Üí- **THEN** the contract returns that depositor's current balance
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer queries any balance

file.content:
## ADDED Requirements

### Requirement: Authorized relayer credit

The `FdcAccounting` contract SHALL accept deposit credits only from the authorized relayer address set at construction time. Any call to `creditDeposit` from a non-relayer address MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`.

#### Scenario: Relayer credits a deposit

- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` with a valid tx hash, depositor address, and non-zero value
- **THEN** the contract records the deposit, increments the depositor's balance by `value`, and emits `DepositCredited(depositor, value, txHash)`

#### Scenario: Non-relayer attempts credit

- **WHEN** any address other than the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit`
- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`

### Requirement: Double-credit prevention

The contract SHALL track processed Sepolia transaction hashes and reject any attempt to credit the same tx hash twice.

#### Scenario: First credit for a tx hash

- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has not been processed before
- **THEN** the deposit is credited and the tx hash is marked as processed

#### Scenario: Duplicate credit attempt

- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has already been processed
- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `AlreadyProcessed(txHash)`

### Requirement: Zero-value rejection

The contract SHALL reject deposits with zero value to prevent meaningless state changes.

#### Scenario: Zero-value deposit

- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with `value = 0`
- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `ZeroValue()`

### Requirement: Private balance storage

Depositor balances SHALL be stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private mapping). Balances MUST NOT be readable by arbitrary external observers.

#### Scenario: Depositor queries own balance

- **WHEN** a depositor calls `getBalance()` from their own address
- **THEN** the contract returns that depositor's current balance

#### Scenario: Relayer queries any balance

- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `getBalanceOf(user)`
- **THEN** the contract returns the specified user's balance

#### Scenario: Unauthorized balance query

- **WHEN** a non-relayer address calls `getBalanceOf(user)` for another user
- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`

- [ ] 1.1 Scaffold `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/` with Hardhat (hardhat.config.ts, package.json, tsconfig)

- [ ] 5.2 Call `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` on the Sapphire accounting contract

## 1. Solidity Contract Setup

- [x] 1.1 Scaffold `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/` with Hardhat (hardhat.config.ts, package.json, tsconfig)
- [x] 1.2 Install Hardhat dependencies (`hardhat`, `@nomicfoundation/hardhat-toolbox`, `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat`)
- [x] 1.3 Write `contracts/FdcAccounting.sol` per the sapphire-accounting spec (creditDeposit, getBalance, getBalanceOf, onlyRelayer, double-credit prevention, zero-value rejection)
- [ ] 1.4 Compile the contract and verify clean build with `npx hardhat compile`

## 2. Relayer TypeScript Setup

- [x] 2.1 Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime` dependency to root package.json
- [ ] 2.2 Create `fdc-trusted-relayer/src/accounting-demo.ts` with provider initialization (Coston2 standard provider, Sapphire wrapped provider)
- [ ] 2.3 Add contract ABI/bytecode import from Hardhat artifacts into the TypeScript relayer

## 3. Contract Deployment Logic

- [ ] 3.1 Implement deploy-or-connect logic: deploy `FdcAccounting` if no address in env, otherwise attach to existing
- [ ] 3.2 Set `authorizedRelayer` to the signer's address on fresh deploy

## 4. FDC Attestation & Verification

- [ ] 4.1 Implement (or import from poc.ts) the FDC attestation flow: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof
- [ ] 4.2 Implement on-chain proof verification via `FdcVerification` view call on Coston2
- [ ] 4.3 Abort relay if proof verification returns false

## 5. Relay to Sapphire

- [ ] 5.1 Extract `sourceAddress`, `value`, and `transactionHash` from verified proof response body
- [ ] 5.2 Call `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` on the Sapphire accounting contract
- [ ] 5.3 Query and log the depositor's balance via `getBalanceOf` after crediting

## 6. Configuration & Wiring

- [ ] 6.1 Update `.env.example` with new vars: `SAPPHIRE_RPC`, `SAPPHIRE_PK`, `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` (optional)
- [ ] 6.2 Add npm script to run the accounting demo (`npm run accounting-demo` or similar)
- [ ] 6.3 Verify full end-to-end flow: deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí query balance

file.content:
## 1. Solidity Contract Setup

- [x] 1.1 Scaffold `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/` with Hardhat (hardhat.config.ts, package.json, tsconfig)
- [x] 1.2 Install Hardhat dependencies (`hardhat`, `@nomicfoundation/hardhat-toolbox`, `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat`)
- [x] 1.3 Write `contracts/FdcAccounting.sol` per the sapphire-accounting spec (creditDeposit, getBalance, getBalanceOf, onlyRelayer, double-credit prevention, zero-value rejection)
- [x] 1.4 Compile the contract and verify clean build with `npx hardhat compile`

## 2. Relayer TypeScript Setup

- [x] 2.1 Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime` dependency to root package.json
- [ ] 2.2 Create `fdc-trusted-relayer/src/accounting-demo.ts` with provider initialization (Coston2 standard provider, Sapphire wrapped provider)
- [ ] 2.3 Add contract ABI/bytecode import from Hardhat artifacts into the TypeScript relayer

## 3. Contract Deployment Logic

- [ ] 3.1 Implement deploy-or-connect logic: deploy `FdcAccounting` if no address in env, otherwise attach to existing
- [ ] 3.2 Set `authorizedRelayer` to the signer's address on fresh deploy

## 4. FDC Attestation & Verification

- [ ] 4.1 Implement (or import from poc.ts) the FDC attestation flow: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof
- [ ] 4.2 Implement on-chain proof verification via `FdcVerification` view call on Coston2
- [ ] 4.3 Abort relay if proof verification returns false

## 5. Relay to Sapphire

- [ ] 5.1 Extract `sourceAddress`, `value`, and `transactionHash` from verified proof response body
- [ ] 5.2 Call `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` on the Sapphire accounting contract
- [ ] 5.3 Query and log the depositor's balance via `getBalanceOf` after crediting

## 6. Configuration & Wiring

- [ ] 6.1 Update `.env.example` with new vars: `SAPPHIRE_RPC`, `SAPPHIRE_PK`, `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` (optional)
- [ ] 6.2 Add npm script to run the accounting demo (`npm run accounting-demo` or similar)
- [ ] 6.3 Verify full end-to-end flow: deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí query balance

You'll need to fund that address on Sapphire testnet. You can do this at https://faucet.oasis.io/ ‚Äî paste `0x998b4BD0D9044a8096e4B81ef421eca4Ed611baC` and select "Sapphire Testnet".

Alternatively, set `SAPPHIRE_PK` in `.env` to a key that's already funded on Sapphire testnet.

content.thinking:
The issue is clear: the Sepolia transaction has `value: 0.0 ETH`, which triggers the `ZeroValue()` revert in the contract. The contract correctly rejects zero-value deposits.

Looking at the output:
```
    Value:      0.0 ETH
```

The Sepolia tx `0xb13ea61f4b638151ebe69c6b61b8fedcd75c9b8e19ecc1b95d2ffe00c2228c41` has a value of 0 ETH ‚Äî it's probably a contract call, not a native ETH transfer. 

The contract is actually working as intended by rejecting the zero-value deposit. The real issue is that the test transaction doesn't include any ETH value, so for a proper end-to-end test we'd need a Sepolia transaction that actually transfers some ETH. That said, this is just a proof of concept and the specific transaction hash comes from the user's environment ‚Äî the entire flow worked correctly through deployment, attestation, and verification, so the revert is just a consequence of this particular transaction being zero-value.

 * FDC Trusted Relayer ‚Äî Sapphire Accounting Demo
 *
 * Fully self-contained end-to-end flow:
 * 0. Send a small ETH transfer to self on Sepolia (creates the tx to attest)
 * 1. Deploy FdcAccounting contract on Sapphire (or connect to existing)
 * 2. Prepare FDC attestation request for the Sepolia tx
 * 3. Submit attestation request to FdcHub on Coston2
 * 4. Wait for proof availability
 * 5. Verify the Merkle proof on-chain
 * 6. Relay verified deposit to the Sapphire accounting contract
 * 7. Query the depositor's private balance
 */

- * 2. Run FDC attestation for a Sepolia tx via Coston2
- * 4. Relay verified deposit to the Sapphire accounting contract

+ * 3. Submit attestation request to FdcHub on Coston2
+ * 6. Relay verified deposit to the Sapphire accounting contract

content.text: Type-check:

Clean. The demo now:

1. **Step 0** ‚Äî Sends `DEPOSIT_AMOUNT` ETH (default 0.0001) to self on Sepolia, captures the tx hash
2. **Steps 1-6** ‚Äî Deploy on Sapphire, attest via FDC, verify, relay, query balance

New env vars needed:
- `SEPOLIA_PK` ‚Äî private key funded with Sepolia ETH (required)
- `SEPOLIA_RPC` ‚Äî optional, defaults to `https://rpc.sepolia.org`
- `DEPOSIT_AMOUNT` ‚Äî optional, defaults to `0.0001`
- `SEPOLIA_TX_HASH` is no longer needed

Want me to add `SEPOLIA_PK` to your `.env` and run it?

content.text: Now create the README for fdc-trusted-relayer:

input.content:
# FDC Trusted Relayer ‚Äî Sapphire Accounting

Cross-chain deposit accounting on Oasis Sapphire using Flare Data Connector (FDC) attestations. Verifies Ethereum Sepolia transactions via FDC Merkle proofs, then credits deposits to a confidential Sapphire smart contract.

## How it works

1. **Sepolia deposit** ‚Äî Sends a small ETH transfer on Sepolia (the "deposit" to attest)
2. **FDC attestation** ‚Äî Submits an attestation request to FdcHub on Coston2 and waits for the voting round to finalize
3. **On-chain verification** ‚Äî Verifies the Merkle proof against Flare's consensus root via `FdcVerification`
4. **Sapphire relay** ‚Äî Calls `creditDeposit()` on the `FdcAccounting` contract deployed on Sapphire testnet
5. **Balance query** ‚Äî Reads the depositor's private balance from Sapphire confidential storage

## Prerequisites

- Node.js and npm
- A private key funded on three testnets (or separate keys per chain):
  - **Sepolia** ‚Äî for the deposit tx ([faucet](https://sepoliafaucet.com/))
  - **Coston2** ‚Äî for FDC attestation fees ([faucet](https://faucet.flare.network/coston2))
  - **Sapphire testnet** ‚Äî for contract deployment + relay tx ([faucet](https://faucet.oasis.io/))

## Setup

```bash
# Install root dependencies (from repo root)
npm install

# Install Hardhat dependencies
cd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npm install && cd ../..

# Compile the Solidity contract
cd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npx hardhat compile && cd ../..
```

Add to `.env` (in repo root):

```
COSTON2_PK=0x...
# Optional: defaults to COSTON2_PK if not set
# SEPOLIA_PK=0x...
# SAPPHIRE_PK=0x...
```

## Run

```bash
npm run accounting-demo
```

The demo is fully self-contained ‚Äî it sends its own Sepolia tx, attests it, and relays the deposit. Takes ~2-3 minutes (mostly waiting for the FDC voting round).

## Contract

`contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol` ‚Äî deployed on Sapphire with:

- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` ‚Äî relayer-only, with double-credit and zero-value protection
- `getBalance()` ‚Äî depositor queries own balance (private storage)
- `getBalanceOf(user)` ‚Äî relayer queries any user's balance

## Configuration

| Variable | Required | Default | Description |
|---|---|---|---|
| `COSTON2_PK` | Yes | ‚Äî | Private key for Coston2 (FDC attestation) |
| `SEPOLIA_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sepolia (deposit tx) |
| `SAPPHIRE_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sapphire (deploy + relay) |
| `SEPOLIA_RPC` | No | `https://ethereum-sepolia-rpc.publicnode.com` | Sepolia RPC endpoint |
| `SAPPHIRE_RPC` | No | `https://testnet.sapphire.oasis.io` | Sapphire RPC endpoint |
| `DEPOSIT_AMOUNT` | No | `0.0001` | ETH amount for the Sepolia deposit |
| `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` | No | ‚Äî | Reuse an existing contract (skips deploy) |

content.text: Looks clean. Committing:

input.command:
git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
Add FDC trusted relayer with Sapphire accounting contract

Self-contained demo that sends a Sepolia ETH transfer, attests it via
FDC on Coston2, verifies the Merkle proof on-chain, and relays the
verified deposit to a confidential FdcAccounting contract on Sapphire.

- FdcAccounting.sol: relayer-only creditDeposit with double-credit
  prevention, zero-value rejection, and private balance storage
- accounting-demo.ts: full e2e flow (Sepolia ‚Üí FDC ‚Üí Sapphire)
- Hardhat project in contracts/ with sapphire-hardhat plugin
- OpenSpec artifacts: proposal, design, specs, tasks (all complete)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

content.content:
1‚Üí## Context
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThe existing `src/poc.ts` demonstrates FDC attestation end-to-end: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof, verify on-chain. This design extends that flow to relay verified deposit data to a Sapphire accounting contract, mirroring FlexVaults' architecture with dramatically less infrastructure.
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe codebase uses TypeScript (strict ESM), ethers.js v6, and runs via tsx. There are no existing Solidity contracts or Hardhat tooling in the project.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Goals / Non-Goals
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí**Goals:**
    10‚Üí- Demonstrate FDC-verified cross-chain deposit accounting on Sapphire with private balances
    11‚Üí- Keep the relayer simple ‚Äî single TypeScript entry point, no queue or persistence
    12‚Üí- Reuse existing FDC attestation logic from `src/poc.ts` where possible
    13‚Üí- Provide a self-contained demo that deploys the contract and runs the full flow
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí**Non-Goals:**
    16‚Üí- Production relayer (no retries, no event watching, no queue)
    17‚Üí- ROFL TEE integration for the relayer (plain EOA signer for PoC)
    18‚Üí- ERC-20 token support (native ETH only)
    19‚Üí- Withdrawals, transfers, or fund locking
    20‚Üí- Mainnet deployment or gas optimization
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí## Decisions
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí### 1. Separate `contracts/` subdirectory with Hardhat
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí**Decision**: Solidity compilation via Hardhat in `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/`, separate from the tsx-based TypeScript runtime.
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí**Rationale**: Hardhat handles Solidity compilation, ABI generation, and deployment scripts cleanly. Keeping it in a subdirectory avoids polluting the root `package.json` with Solidity tooling.
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Inline ABI as a JSON constant in TypeScript. Rejected because it makes the contract source non-compilable and harder to verify/modify.
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí### 2. Single-file relayer at `src/accounting-demo.ts`
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí**Decision**: One TypeScript file orchestrates the full flow (deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí relay ‚Üí query).
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí**Rationale**: Matches the project's existing pattern (`src/poc.ts` is single-file). For a PoC, a linear script is clearer than a modular architecture.
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Extract shared FDC logic into a library module. Worth doing if the codebase grows, but premature for two files.
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### 3. Sapphire provider wrapping with `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime`
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí**Decision**: Wrap the ethers.js provider with `sapphire.wrap()` for automatic transaction encryption.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**Rationale**: This is the standard Sapphire integration pattern. It encrypts calldata so balance queries and deposits stay confidential on-chain.
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí### 4. Contract deploys fresh each run (no address persistence)
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí**Decision**: The demo script deploys `FdcAccounting` on each run rather than persisting a contract address.
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí**Rationale**: Simplifies the PoC ‚Äî no state file or env var management for contract addresses. The demo is self-contained. Users can easily modify to connect to an existing deployment.
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí### 5. Double-credit prevention via tx hash mapping
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí**Decision**: `processedTxHashes` mapping in the contract prevents the same Sepolia tx from being credited twice.
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí**Rationale**: Essential correctness property. Even though the PoC relayer only runs once, the contract must be safe against replays for any real usage.
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí## Risks / Trade-offs
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí- **[Trusted relayer is a single point of trust]** ‚Üí Acceptable for PoC. In production, wrap in ROFL TEE or use multisig. The contract's `onlyRelayer` modifier is already designed for a single authorized address, which maps cleanly to a ROFL app address.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí- **[FDC proof verified on Coston2, not on Sapphire]** ‚Üí The relayer bridges two separate chains. The Sapphire contract trusts the relayer's attestation. This is architecturally identical to FlexVaults (ROFL backend verifies proof, then writes to Sapphire).
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí- **[Sapphire testnet availability]** ‚Üí Sapphire testnet may have downtime. No mitigation needed for a PoC.
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí- **[Hardhat adds dependency weight]** ‚Üí Only needed in `contracts/` subdirectory. Does not affect the tsx runtime. Could use solc directly but Hardhat provides better DX for deployment.
    67‚Üí

content.content:
1‚Üí## ADDED Requirements
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí### Requirement: Authorized relayer credit
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe `FdcAccounting` contract SHALL accept deposit credits only from the authorized relayer address set at construction time. Any call to `creditDeposit` from a non-relayer address MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer credits a deposit
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` with a valid tx hash, depositor address, and non-zero value
    10‚Üí- **THEN** the contract records the deposit, increments the depositor's balance by `value`, and emits `DepositCredited(depositor, value, txHash)`
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí#### Scenario: Non-relayer attempts credit
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí- **WHEN** any address other than the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit`
    15‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí### Requirement: Double-credit prevention
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíThe contract SHALL track processed Sepolia transaction hashes and reject any attempt to credit the same tx hash twice.
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí#### Scenario: First credit for a tx hash
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has not been processed before
    24‚Üí- **THEN** the deposit is credited and the tx hash is marked as processed
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí#### Scenario: Duplicate credit attempt
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has already been processed
    29‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `AlreadyProcessed(txHash)`
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí### Requirement: Zero-value rejection
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThe contract SHALL reject deposits with zero value to prevent meaningless state changes.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí#### Scenario: Zero-value deposit
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with `value = 0`
    38‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `ZeroValue()`
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### Requirement: Private balance storage
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíDepositor balances SHALL be stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private mapping). Balances MUST NOT be readable by arbitrary external observers.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí#### Scenario: Depositor queries own balance
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí- **WHEN** a depositor calls `getBalance()` from their own address
    47‚Üí- **THEN** the contract returns that depositor's current balance
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer queries any balance
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `getBalanceOf(user)`
    52‚Üí- **THEN** the contract returns the specified user's balance
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí#### Scenario: Unauthorized balance query
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí- **WHEN** a non-relayer address calls `getBalanceOf(user)` for another user
    57‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`
    58‚Üí

content.content:
1‚Üí# FDC Trusted Relayer ‚Äî Sapphire Accounting
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíCross-chain deposit accounting on Oasis Sapphire using Flare Data Connector (FDC) attestations. Verifies Ethereum Sepolia transactions via FDC Merkle proofs, then credits deposits to a confidential Sapphire smart contract.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## How it works
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí1. **Sepolia deposit** ‚Äî Sends a small ETH transfer on Sepolia (the "deposit" to attest)
     8‚Üí2. **FDC attestation** ‚Äî Submits an attestation request to FdcHub on Coston2 and waits for the voting round to finalize
     9‚Üí3. **On-chain verification** ‚Äî Verifies the Merkle proof against Flare's consensus root via `FdcVerification`
    10‚Üí4. **Sapphire relay** ‚Äî Calls `creditDeposit()` on the `FdcAccounting` contract deployed on Sapphire testnet
    11‚Üí5. **Balance query** ‚Äî Reads the depositor's private balance from Sapphire confidential storage
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## Prerequisites
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí- Node.js and npm
    16‚Üí- A private key funded on three testnets (or separate keys per chain):
    17‚Üí  - **Sepolia** ‚Äî for the deposit tx ([faucet](https://sepoliafaucet.com/))
    18‚Üí  - **Coston2** ‚Äî for FDC attestation fees ([faucet](https://faucet.flare.network/coston2))
    19‚Üí  - **Sapphire testnet** ‚Äî for contract deployment + relay tx ([faucet](https://faucet.oasis.io/))
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí## Setup
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí```bash
    24‚Üí# Install root dependencies (from repo root)
    25‚Üínpm install
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí# Install Hardhat dependencies
    28‚Üícd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npm install && cd ../..
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí# Compile the Solidity contract
    31‚Üícd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npx hardhat compile && cd ../..
    32‚Üí```
    33‚Üí
    34‚ÜíAdd to `.env` (in repo root):
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí```
    37‚ÜíCOSTON2_PK=0x...
    38‚Üí# Optional: defaults to COSTON2_PK if not set
    39‚Üí# SEPOLIA_PK=0x...
    40‚Üí# SAPPHIRE_PK=0x...
    41‚Üí```
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí## Run
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí```bash
    46‚Üínpm run accounting-demo
    47‚Üí```
    48‚Üí
    49‚ÜíThe demo is fully self-contained ‚Äî it sends its own Sepolia tx, attests it, and relays the deposit. Takes ~2-3 minutes (mostly waiting for the FDC voting round).
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí## Contract
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí`contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol` ‚Äî deployed on Sapphire with:
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` ‚Äî relayer-only, with double-credit and zero-value protection
    56‚Üí- `getBalance()` ‚Äî depositor queries own balance (private storage)
    57‚Üí- `getBalanceOf(user)` ‚Äî relayer queries any user's balance
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí## Configuration
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí| Variable | Required | Default | Description |
    62‚Üí|---|---|---|---|
    63‚Üí| `COSTON2_PK` | Yes | ‚Äî | Private key for Coston2 (FDC attestation) |
    64‚Üí| `SEPOLIA_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sepolia (deposit tx) |
    65‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sapphire (deploy + relay) |
    66‚Üí| `SEPOLIA_RPC` | No | `https://ethereum-sepolia-rpc.publicnode.com` | Sepolia RPC endpoint |
    67‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_RPC` | No | `https://testnet.sapphire.oasis.io` | Sapphire RPC endpoint |
    68‚Üí| `DEPOSIT_AMOUNT` | No | `0.0001` | ETH amount for the Sepolia deposit |
    69‚Üí| `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` | No | ‚Äî | Reuse an existing contract (skips deploy) |
    70‚Üí

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Sapphire and the Confidential EVM, though the specific term "flexvaults" and "encumbered accounts" don't appear in the available search results. Here's what I found:

## Sapphire: The Confidential EVM

Sapphire is the first confidential EVM, an Ethereum-compatible execution environment where smart contract calldata and storage are encrypted by default. It combines the familiarity of Solidity with the confidentiality of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), enabling developers to build privacy-preserving dApps without leaving the EVM ecosystem.

### How It Works

Sapphire is the Confidential EVM ParaTime, powered by Intel SGX/TDX trusted execution environments to ensure data privacy during computation, with compute nodes executing the contract inside TEE enclaves. Validators reach consensus on transaction ordering and finality, but never see the underlying plaintext data.

### Key Features

Developers can build EVM-based on-chain dApps with smart contracts that are 100% confidential, 100% public, or anywhere in between. Developers can selectively expose state, events, or return values using provided runtime APIs, flipping the usual blockchain model to opt-in transparency, with all inputs, storage, and outputs encrypted unless explicitly exposed.

### Oasis Privacy Layer (OPL)

Sapphire is fully compatible with the Oasis Privacy Layer (OPL), a bridge framework connecting contracts on other EVM chains (like Ethereum, Base, or Arbitrum) to a Sapphire enclave for confidential execution.

Regarding "flexvaults" and "encumbered accounts" specifically, these terms don't appear in the available search results about Sapphire. content.content:
1‚Üí# FlexVaults (Accounting Module) ‚Äî Knowledge Document
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí> Source: [rube-de/flexvaults-test](https://github.com/rube-de/flexvaults-test) (private)
     4‚Üí> License: MIT
     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí## What It Does
     7‚Üí
     8‚ÜíA reusable ROFL-based accounting module that provides:
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí- **Cross-chain deposits** ‚Äî users deposit native tokens or ERC-20s on any EVM chain; the module verifies the deposit on Oasis Sapphire via transaction inclusion proofs and credits the user's balance.
    11‚Üí- **Private accounting** ‚Äî all balances, locks, and transfers are managed on Sapphire, invisible to the public.
    12‚Üí- **Fund locking** ‚Äî users can lock funds for services (e.g. a game or escrow), authorized via EIP-712 signatures.
    13‚Üí- **Cross-chain withdrawals** ‚Äî the contract generates and signs withdrawal transactions on Sapphire using the `EIP155Signer` precompile, and the backend broadcasts them to the destination chain.
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## Architecture Overview
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí```
    18‚ÜíSource Chain (e.g. Base Sepolia)        Oasis Sapphire
    19‚Üí‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê                ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    20‚Üí‚îÇ  User sends ETH or   ‚îÇ                ‚îÇ        Accounting.sol        ‚îÇ
    21‚Üí‚îÇ  ERC-20 to deposit   ‚îÇ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ proofs ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ>‚îÇ  creditEVMDeposit()          ‚îÇ
    22‚Üí‚îÇ  address             ‚îÇ                ‚îÇ  createLock() / modifyLock() ‚îÇ
    23‚Üí‚îÇ                      ‚îÇ                ‚îÇ  transferBalance()           ‚îÇ
    24‚Üí‚îÇ                      ‚îÇ<‚îÄ‚îÄ signed tx ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÇ  requestWithdrawal()         ‚îÇ
    25‚Üí‚îÇ  User receives       ‚îÇ                ‚îÇ  resolveWithdrawal()         ‚îÇ
    26‚Üí‚îÇ  withdrawal          ‚îÇ                ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    27‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò                           ‚îÇ inherits
    28‚Üí                                         ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    29‚Üí                                         ‚îÇ                     ‚îÇ
    30‚Üí                                ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê   ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    31‚Üí                                ‚îÇEIP712Signature‚îÇ   ‚îÇEVMSignerAndVerifier‚îÇ
    32‚Üí                                ‚îÇ  Verifier     ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ (tx decode, sign,  ‚îÇ
    33‚Üí                                ‚îÇ               ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ  proof verify)     ‚îÇ
    34‚Üí                                ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    35‚Üí                                                              ‚îÇ inherits
    36‚Üí                                                    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    37‚Üí                                                    ‚îÇ  ProvethVerifier   ‚îÇ
    38‚Üí                                                    ‚îÇ (Merkle Patricia   ‚îÇ
    39‚Üí                                                    ‚îÇ  Trie proofs)      ‚îÇ
    40‚Üí                                                    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíPython Backend (FastAPI in ROFL TEE)
    43‚Üí‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    44‚Üí‚îÇ  DepositListener  ‚Äî polls source chains for deposits to deposit addr ‚îÇ
    45‚Üí‚îÇ  WithdrawalProcessor ‚Äî polls for pending withdrawals, resolves/bcasts‚îÇ
    46‚Üí‚îÇ  ProofGenerator   ‚Äî builds tx + receipt Merkle Patricia Trie proofs  ‚îÇ
    47‚Üí‚îÇ  AccountingContractService ‚Äî submits txs to Accounting via ROFL      ‚îÇ
    48‚Üí‚îÇ  RoflAppdClient   ‚Äî ROFL daemon client (key gen, tx sign+submit)     ‚îÇ
    49‚Üí‚îÇ  FastAPI routes    ‚Äî REST API at /v1/accounting/*                     ‚îÇ
    50‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    51‚Üí```
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí## Smart Contracts
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí### Accounting.sol (main contract)
    56‚Üí
    57‚ÜíThe central ledger. Manages `mapping(address => mapping(bytes32 tokenId => uint256))` balances. Inherits `EIP712SignatureVerifier` and `EVMSignerAndVerifier`.
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí**Deposit flow:**
    60‚Üí- `creditEVMDeposit(userAddress, tokenId, txProof, receiptProof)` ‚Äî verifies both the transaction and receipt inclusion proofs via `ProvethVerifier`, decodes the raw EVM transaction (supports Legacy, EIP-2930, EIP-1559), verifies the block hash via ShoyuBashi oracle, validates sender/recipient/amount, and credits the user's balance.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí**Fund locking:**
    63‚Üí- `createLock(user, service, tokenId, amount, expiry, signature)` ‚Äî moves funds from balance to a time-locked escrow. Max 10 active locks per user.
    64‚Üí- `modifyLock(user, lockId, amount, newExpiry, signature)` ‚Äî add funds or extend expiry on an existing lock.
    65‚Üí- `transferFromLock(user, to, lockId, amount, signature)` ‚Äî the *service* signs to authorize transferring locked funds to a recipient.
    66‚Üí- `unlockSingleLock(user, lockId)` / `unlockAllExpiredLocks(user)` ‚Äî reclaim expired locks.
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí**Transfers:**
    69‚Üí- `transferBalance(user, to, tokenId, amount, signature)` ‚Äî off-chain-signed peer-to-peer transfer within the ledger.
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí**Withdrawal flow:**
    72‚Üí- `requestWithdrawal(user, tokenId, amount, nonce, signature)` ‚Äî debits balance, records a `WithdrawalRequest` with a chain-specific nonce.
    73‚Üí- `resolveWithdrawal(index)` ‚Äî generates a signed EVM transaction (via Sapphire's `EIP155Signer` precompile) for the destination chain. Idempotent ‚Äî can be called multiple times to retry broadcast.
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**Token registry:**
    76‚Üí- `setTokenInfo(TokenInfo)` ‚Äî owner registers supported tokens.
    77‚Üí- `getTokenId(TokenInfo)` ‚Äî deterministic `keccak256(abi.encode(tokenType, data))`.
    78‚Üí- Token types: `NativeEVM` (32 bytes: chainId) or `ERC20` (52 bytes: chainId + address).
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí### EVMSignerAndVerifier.sol
    81‚Üí
    82‚ÜíHandles the cryptographic heavy lifting:
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí- **Transaction decoding** ‚Äî `decodeEVMTransaction()` supports Legacy (>= 0xc0), EIP-2930 (type 1), and EIP-1559 (type 2) transactions. Recovers sender via ECDSA.
    85‚Üí- **Transaction signing** ‚Äî `generateNativeTransfer()` and `generateERC20Transfer()` use Sapphire's `EIP155Signer.sign()` precompile with a secret key generated at deployment via `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()`.
    86‚Üí- **Block hash verification** ‚Äî `verifyBlockHash()` queries `ShoyuBashi.getUnanimousHash(chainId, blockNumber)`.
    87‚Üí- **Receipt decoding** ‚Äî `decodeEVMTxReceipt()` extracts status and gas used.
    88‚Üí- **Nonce management** ‚Äî per-chain nonces for withdrawal transactions.
    89‚Üí- **Gas price management** ‚Äî `setGasPrice(chainId, gasPrice)` ‚Äî owner-only, must be set before generating withdrawal txs.
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí### EIP712SignatureVerifier.sol
    92‚Üí
    93‚ÜíTyped data signing for all user operations:
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí| Operation | Type Hash | Signer |
    96‚Üí|---|---|---|
    97‚Üí| `Withdraw` | `Withdraw(address userAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount,uint256 nonce)` | User |
    98‚Üí| `Lock` | `Lock(address userAddress,address serviceAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount,uint256 expiry)` | User |
    99‚Üí| `Transfer` | `Transfer(address userAddress,address toAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount)` | User |
   100‚Üí| `TransferLocked` | `TransferLocked(address userAddress,address toAddress,uint256 lockId,uint256 amount)` | Service |
   101‚Üí| `ModifyLock` | `ModifyLock(address userAddress,uint256 lockId,uint256 amount,uint256 newExpiry)` | User |
   102‚Üí
   103‚ÜíDomain: `name="AccountingModule"`, `version="1"`. Signatures are single-use (tracked in `usedSignatures` mapping). Withdrawals use a per-user nonce instead.
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí### ProvethVerifier.sol
   106‚Üí
   107‚ÜíMerkle Patricia Trie proof verification for both transactions and receipts. Validates proofs against `transactionsRoot` and `receiptsRoot` in the block header.
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí### ShoyuBashi (external ‚Äî Hashi)
   110‚Üí
   111‚ÜíMulti-oracle block hash consensus system. The `Accounting` contract calls `shoyuBashi.getUnanimousHash(chainId, blockNumber)` to verify that the block hash in a deposit proof is legitimate. The ROFL Header Oracle (see [rofl-header-oracle.md](./rofl-header-oracle.md)) feeds block hashes into the `ROFLAdapter`, which is one of ShoyuBashi's configured adapters.
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí## Python Backend
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí### Tech Stack
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí- **FastAPI** (uvicorn) ‚Äî REST API
   118‚Üí- **web3.py** ‚Äî blockchain interaction
   119‚Üí- **oasis-rofl-client** ‚Äî ROFL daemon communication
   120‚Üí- **rlp** / **trie** (HexaryTrie) ‚Äî Merkle Patricia Trie proof generation
   121‚Üí- **cbor2** ‚Äî ROFL response decoding
   122‚Üí- Runs in Docker inside a ROFL TEE container (TDX)
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí### Key Services
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí**DepositListener** (`src/services/deposit_listener.py`)
   127‚Üí- Polls configured source chains for incoming transfers to the deposit address (both native and ERC-20 `Transfer` events).
   128‚Üí- Waits for the block hash to appear in the ROFLAdapter on Sapphire (via `getHash(chainId, blockNumber)`).
   129‚Üí- Generates Merkle Patricia Trie proofs (tx proof + receipt proof) using `debug_getRawBlock` and `debug_getRawReceipts` RPCs.
   130‚Üí- Submits `creditEVMDeposit()` to the Accounting contract via ROFL.
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí**WithdrawalProcessor** (`src/services/withdrawal_processor.py`)
   133‚Üí- Polls for pending `WithdrawalRequest` entries in the Accounting contract.
   134‚Üí- Calls `resolveWithdrawal(index)` to get a signed transaction from the contract.
   135‚Üí- Broadcasts the signed tx to the destination chain.
   136‚Üí- Includes a catch-up mechanism that compares contract nonces vs destination chain nonces to find and re-broadcast missing withdrawals.
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí**ProofGenerator** (`src/services/proof_generator.py`)
   139‚Üí- Builds both transaction and receipt Merkle Patricia Trie inclusion proofs.
   140‚Üí- Uses `debug_getRawBlock` to get raw block data and reconstruct the trie.
   141‚Üí- Uses `debug_getRawReceipts` for receipt proofs.
   142‚Üí- Requires archive node access with debug API enabled.
   143‚Üí
   144‚Üí**AccountingContractService** (`src/services/accounting_contract.py`)
   145‚Üí- Wraps all contract interactions: deposits, locks, transfers, withdrawals.
   146‚Üí- Submits transactions via the `RoflAppdClient`.
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí**RoflAppdClient** (`src/clients/rofl.py`)
   149‚Üí- Singleton wrapper around `oasis-rofl-client`.
   150‚Üí- `get_keypair(key_id)` ‚Äî generates secp256k1 keys via ROFL daemon.
   151‚Üí- `submit_tx(tx)` ‚Äî signs and submits transactions, decodes CBOR responses, detects reverts by decoding error selectors.
   152‚Üí
   153‚Üí### REST API
   154‚Üí
   155‚ÜíAll routes under `/v1/accounting/`:
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí| Method | Endpoint | Description |
   158‚Üí|---|---|---|
   159‚Üí| POST | `/quote/deposit` | Get deposit instructions (address, tx data) |
   160‚Üí| POST | `/deposits` | Submit deposit inclusion proof |
   161‚Üí| POST | `/funds/lock` | Lock funds for a service |
   162‚Üí| POST | `/funds/modify-lock` | Modify an existing lock |
   163‚Üí| POST | `/funds/transfer` | Transfer between users |
   164‚Üí| POST | `/funds/transfer-locked` | Transfer from locked funds (service-signed) |
   165‚Üí| POST | `/funds/unlock` | Unlock expired lock |
   166‚Üí| POST | `/funds/unlock-all-expired` | Unlock all expired locks |
   167‚Üí| POST | `/withdrawals` | Request withdrawal |
   168‚Üí| GET | `/balances/{user}/{tokenId}` | Get user balance |
   169‚Üí| POST | `/balances/batch` | Get multiple balances |
   170‚Üí| GET | `/locks/{user}` | Get user's active locks |
   171‚Üí| GET | `/locks/{user}/expired` | Get expired locks |
   172‚Üí| GET | `/tokens/{tokenId}` | Get token info |
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí### Configuration
   175‚Üí
   176‚ÜíEnvironment variables (loaded via `src/config/__init__.py`):
   177‚Üí
   178‚Üí| Variable | Description |
   179‚Üí|---|---|
   180‚Üí| `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` | Accounting contract on Sapphire |
   181‚Üí| `ROFL_ADAPTER_ADDRESS` | ROFLAdapter for block hash lookups |
   182‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_RPC_URL` | Sapphire RPC endpoint |
   183‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_CHAIN_ID` | Sapphire chain ID |
   184‚Üí| `ALCHEMY_API_KEY` | Used to construct source chain RPC URLs |
   185‚Üí| `DEPOSIT_POLL_INTERVAL` | Seconds between deposit checks |
   186‚Üí
   187‚ÜíCurrently configured for **Base Sepolia** (chain ID 84532) as the source chain, with USDC ERC-20 support.
   188‚Üí
   189‚Üí## Deployment
   190‚Üí
   191‚Üí- **ROFL TEE:** TDX container, 1 CPU, 1GB RAM, 8GB persistent disk
   192‚Üí- **Docker:** Multi-stage build (see `Dockerfile`)
   193‚Üí- **Secrets:** Encrypted in `rofl.yaml` via ROFL secrets management
   194‚Üí- **Solidity tooling:** Hardhat with Sapphire plugin, deployed via `npx hardhat deploy --shoyubashi <addr>`
   195‚Üí
   196‚Üí## Security Model
   197‚Üí
   198‚Üí1. **Deposit verification** ‚Äî tx + receipt Merkle Patricia Trie proofs verified on-chain by ProvethVerifier, block hash consensus via ShoyuBashi (multi-oracle).
   199‚Üí2. **User authorization** ‚Äî all balance-affecting operations require EIP-712 typed data signatures; signatures are single-use.
   200‚Üí3. **Withdrawal security** ‚Äî private key for destination chain signing lives only in the Sapphire contract (generated via `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()`). Resolution requires a block delay to prevent simulation attacks.
   201‚Üí4. **TEE isolation** ‚Äî backend runs inside ROFL TDX enclave. ROFL daemon handles key derivation and transaction signing.
   202‚Üí
   203‚Üí## Relevance to Flare FDC PoC
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí| FlexVaults | Flare FDC PoC |
   206‚Üí|---|---|
   207‚Üí| Verifies source chain txs via Merkle Patricia Trie proofs (ProvethVerifier) | Verifies Sepolia txs via FDC attestation + Merkle proof against attestation root |
   208‚Üí| Block hash trust via ShoyuBashi (multi-oracle consensus) | Block/tx trust via FDC attestation providers (decentralized voting) |
   209‚Üí| Full tx decoding on-chain (Legacy, EIP-2930, EIP-1559) | Verifies specific tx fields via FDC response structure |
   210‚Üí| Proof generation uses `debug_getRawBlock` + HexaryTrie | Proof generation handled by FDC protocol / attestation clients |
   211‚Üí| Balances live on Sapphire (private) | Verification result lives on Coston2 (public) |
   212‚Üí| Two-phase withdrawal (request -> resolve -> broadcast) | Single-step attestation verification |
   213‚Üí
   214‚ÜíThe key shared concept is **transaction inclusion proofs**: both systems need to prove that a specific transaction was included in a specific block on the source chain, and both verify this against a trusted block hash. FlexVaults does the Merkle proof verification itself on-chain, while the Flare FDC delegates proof verification to a network of attestation providers.
   215‚Üí

content.content:
1‚Üí# Plan 1: Trusted Relayer Backend
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## Overview
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíA TypeScript backend verifies the FDC proof on Coston2 (view call to `FdcVerification`), then submits the verified transaction data to a Sapphire accounting contract as an authorized signer. This mirrors FlexVaults' trust model (ROFL TEE backend -> Sapphire contract) but replaces proof generation entirely with FDC.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Architecture
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí```
    10‚ÜíSepolia                    Coston2 (Flare)              Oasis Sapphire
    11‚Üí+----------------+         +-------------------+        +-----------------------+
    12‚Üí| User sends     |         | FDC attestation   |        | FdcAccounting.sol     |
    13‚Üí| ETH deposit    |         | providers vote    |        | (private balances)    |
    14‚Üí|                |         |                   |        |                       |
    15‚Üí|                |         | FdcVerification   |        | creditDeposit()       |
    16‚Üí|                |         | .verifyEVM...()   |        | getBalance()          |
    17‚Üí+-------+--------+         +--------+----------+        +----------+------------+
    18‚Üí        |                           |                              |
    19‚Üí        |                    TypeScript Backend                    |
    20‚Üí        |              +-------------------------------+           |
    21‚Üí        |              | 1. Request FDC attestation    |           |
    22‚Üí        |              | 2. Wait for proof (~2-3 min)  |           |
    23‚Üí        |              | 3. Verify on Coston2 (view)   |-- verify -+
    24‚Üí        |              | 4. Submit to Sapphire         |-- credit -+
    25‚Üí        |              +-------------------------------+
    26‚Üí```
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí## Trust Model
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí| Component | FlexVaults | This PoC |
    31‚Üí|---|---|---|
    32‚Üí| Proof generation | Python backend + `debug_getRawBlock` + HexaryTrie | FDC attestation providers (fully managed) |
    33‚Üí| Block hash trust | ROFL TEE -> ROFLAdapter -> ShoyuBashi | FDC decentralized voting (50%+ provider consensus) |
    34‚Üí| Proof verification | ProvethVerifier on Sapphire (~400 lines) | FdcVerification on Coston2 (1 view call) |
    35‚Üí| Backend trust anchor | ROFL TEE attestation (`onlyROFL` modifier) | Authorized signer (EOA or could be ROFL TEE) |
    36‚Üí| Balance privacy | Sapphire confidential compute | Sapphire confidential compute (same) |
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Key tradeoff**: The backend is trusted to relay accurate FDC results. In production, this relayer could itself run inside a ROFL TEE for the same trust guarantees as FlexVaults, or a multisig/threshold scheme could be used. For the PoC, a simple authorized signer demonstrates the concept.
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí## Sapphire Contract: `FdcAccounting.sol`
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí```solidity
    43‚Üí// SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT
    44‚Üípragma solidity ^0.8.20;
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üícontract FdcAccounting {
    47‚Üí    address public immutable authorizedRelayer;
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí    // Private balances (Sapphire confidential storage)
    50‚Üí    mapping(address depositor => uint256 balance) private balances;
    51‚Üí    mapping(bytes32 txHash => bool processed) public processedTxHashes;
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí    event DepositCredited(address indexed depositor, uint256 amount, bytes32 indexed txHash);
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí    error Unauthorized();
    56‚Üí    error AlreadyProcessed(bytes32 txHash);
    57‚Üí    error ZeroValue();
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí    modifier onlyRelayer() {
    60‚Üí        if (msg.sender != authorizedRelayer) revert Unauthorized();
    61‚Üí        _;
    62‚Üí    }
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí    constructor(address _relayer) {
    65‚Üí        authorizedRelayer = _relayer;
    66‚Üí    }
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí    /// @notice Credit a deposit after the relayer has verified the FDC proof on Coston2.
    69‚Üí    /// @param txHash The Sepolia transaction hash (prevents double-crediting)
    70‚Üí    /// @param depositor The sender address on Sepolia (from FDC responseBody.sourceAddress)
    71‚Üí    /// @param value The ETH value in wei (from FDC responseBody.value)
    72‚Üí    function creditDeposit(
    73‚Üí        bytes32 txHash,
    74‚Üí        address depositor,
    75‚Üí        uint256 value
    76‚Üí    ) external onlyRelayer {
    77‚Üí        if (processedTxHashes[txHash]) revert AlreadyProcessed(txHash);
    78‚Üí        if (value == 0) revert ZeroValue();
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí        processedTxHashes[txHash] = true;
    81‚Üí        balances[depositor] += value;
    82‚Üí
    83‚Üí        emit DepositCredited(depositor, value, txHash);
    84‚Üí    }
    85‚Üí
    86‚Üí    /// @notice Query balance (only callable by the depositor themselves for privacy)
    87‚Üí    function getBalance() external view returns (uint256) {
    88‚Üí        return balances[msg.sender];
    89‚Üí    }
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí    /// @notice Relayer can query any balance (for operational purposes)
    92‚Üí    function getBalanceOf(address user) external view onlyRelayer returns (uint256) {
    93‚Üí        return balances[user];
    94‚Üí    }
    95‚Üí}
    96‚Üí```
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí## TypeScript Backend Flow
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí```typescript
   101‚Üí// src/accounting-demo.ts
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí// Step 0: Connect to both chains
   104‚Üíconst coston2Provider = new ethers.JsonRpcProvider(COSTON2_RPC);
   105‚Üíconst sapphireProvider = sapphire.wrap(new ethers.JsonRpcProvider(SAPPHIRE_RPC));
   106‚Üíconst signer = new ethers.Wallet(PRIVATE_KEY, sapphireProvider);
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí// Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire (or connect to existing)
   109‚Üíconst accounting = await deployOrConnect(signer);
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí// Step 2-4: FDC attestation on Coston2 (reuse from fdc.ts)
   112‚Üíconst abiEncodedRequest = await prepareAttestationRequest(sepoliaTxHash);
   113‚Üíconst { votingRoundId } = await submitAttestationRequest(coston2Signer, abiEncodedRequest);
   114‚Üíconst proofData = await waitForProof(votingRoundId, abiEncodedRequest);
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí// Step 5: Verify FDC proof on Coston2 (view call -- no gas)
   117‚Üíconst isValid = await verifyOnChain(coston2Provider, proofData);
   118‚Üíassert(isValid, "FDC proof invalid");
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí// Step 6: Relay verified data to Sapphire
   121‚Üíconst { sourceAddress, value } = proofData.response.responseBody;
   122‚Üíconst txHash = proofData.response.requestBody.transactionHash;
   123‚Üíawait accounting.creditDeposit(txHash, sourceAddress, BigInt(value));
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí// Step 7: Query balance on Sapphire
   126‚Üíconst balance = await accounting.getBalanceOf(sourceAddress);
   127‚Üíconsole.log(`Balance credited: ${ethers.formatEther(balance)} ETH`);
   128‚Üí```
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí## Dependencies
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí- Existing: ethers.js, @flarenetwork/flare-tx-sdk, dotenv, tsx
   133‚Üí- New: `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime` (wraps ethers provider for Sapphire encrypted txs)
   134‚Üí- Hardhat in `contracts/` subdirectory (for Solidity compilation)
   135‚Üí
   136‚Üí## What This Proves
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí1. FDC attestation provides all data FlexVaults needs (sender, receiver, value, status)
   139‚Üí2. No ROFL oracle, ShoyuBashi, or ProvethVerifier needed
   140‚Üí3. Accounting stays on Sapphire (private balances)
   141‚Üí4. Backend trust model is equivalent to FlexVaults (trusted relayer)
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí## Limitations
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí- Relayer is a simple EOA (FlexVaults uses ROFL TEE attestation)
   146‚Üí- No ERC-20 support (only native ETH)
   147‚Üí- No fund locking, transfers, or withdrawals (deposit crediting only)
   148‚Üí- The FDC proof is verified off-Sapphire (Coston2 view call), then relayed
   149‚Üí
   150‚Üí## Complexity
   151‚Üí
   152‚Üí- ~80 lines Solidity (vs ~1000+ lines in FlexVaults contracts)
   153‚Üí- ~200 lines TypeScript (vs ~600 lines Python backend in FlexVaults)
   154‚Üí- Zero infrastructure (vs ROFL TEE + oracle + Hashi)
   155‚Üí

1‚Üí# Plan 2: On-Chain Merkle Verification on Sapphire
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## Overview
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíPort the FDC Merkle proof verification logic directly to Sapphire, so the accounting contract can verify FDC proofs without any trusted relayer or Coston2 interaction at transaction time. The FDC Merkle root is synced from Coston2 to Sapphire, and the contract verifies proofs locally.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Architecture
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí```
    10‚ÜíSepolia                    Coston2 (Flare)              Oasis Sapphire
    11‚Üí+----------------+         +-------------------+        +------------------------------+
    12‚Üí| User sends     |         | FDC providers     |        | FdcAccountingTrustless.sol   |
    13‚Üí| ETH deposit    |         | vote on Merkle    |        |                              |
    14‚Üí|                |         | root each round   |        | verifyAndCredit(proof)       |
    15‚Üí|                |         |                   |        | |-- check Merkle root        |
    16‚Üí|                |         | Relay contract    |        | |-- verify Merkle proof      |
    17‚Üí|                |         | stores roots      |        | +-- credit balance           |
    18‚Üí+-------+--------+         +--------+----------+        +-------------+----------------+
    19‚Üí        |                           |                                 |
    20‚Üí        |                    TypeScript Backend                       |
    21‚Üí        |              +--------------------------------+             |
    22‚Üí        |              | 1. Request FDC attestation     |             |
    23‚Üí        |              | 2. Wait for proof (~2-3 min)   |             |
    24‚Üí        |              | 3. Sync Merkle root to         |--- root ----+
    25‚Üí        |              |    Sapphire (if needed)         |
    26‚Üí        |              | 4. Submit proof to Sapphire     |--- proof ---+
    27‚Üí        |              |    (contract verifies locally)  |
    28‚Üí        |              +--------------------------------+
    29‚Üí```
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí## How FDC Merkle Verification Works
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThe FDC `FdcVerification` contract on Coston2 does three things:
    34‚Üí1. **Reconstruct the leaf**: Hash the attestation response data (tx details, block number, events, etc.) into a `bytes32` leaf
    35‚Üí2. **Compute the root**: Walk the Merkle proof path from leaf to root using `keccak256` hashing
    36‚Üí3. **Compare**: Check that the computed root matches the root stored in the `Relay` contract for that voting round
    37‚Üí
    38‚ÜíTo port this to Sapphire, we need:
    39‚Üí- The **leaf reconstruction** logic (hash the response struct)
    40‚Üí- The **Merkle proof walk** logic (standard binary Merkle tree)
    41‚Üí- A **root store** on Sapphire (synced from Coston2's Relay contract)
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí## Trust Model
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí| Component | FlexVaults | This PoC |
    46‚Üí|---|---|---|
    47‚Üí| Proof generation | Python backend | FDC protocol (managed) |
    48‚Üí| Block hash trust | ShoyuBashi multi-oracle | FDC Merkle root (50%+ provider consensus) |
    49‚Üí| Proof verification | ProvethVerifier on Sapphire | FDC Merkle verifier on Sapphire |
    50‚Üí| Root source | ROFL oracle relays block headers | Backend relays FDC Merkle roots |
    51‚Üí| Backend trust | ROFL TEE (for relay + proof gen) | Only relays roots (can't forge proofs) |
    52‚Üí| Balance privacy | Sapphire | Sapphire (same) |
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí**Key advantage over Plan 1**: The backend only needs to relay Merkle roots -- it cannot fabricate deposits because the Merkle proof must verify against the root. This is analogous to how FlexVaults trusts ShoyuBashi for block hashes but verifies proofs independently.
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí**Key advantage over FlexVaults**: No ROFL TEE needed for proof generation. FDC handles proof generation off-chain. The Sapphire contract only needs ~50 lines of Merkle verification (vs ~400 lines of ProvethVerifier MPT logic).
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí## Sapphire Contract: `FdcAccountingTrustless.sol`
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí```solidity
    61‚Üí// SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT
    62‚Üípragma solidity ^0.8.20;
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üícontract FdcAccountingTrustless {
    65‚Üí    address public rootRelayer;       // Can only set Merkle roots (not forge proofs)
    66‚Üí    address public immutable depositAddress;
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí    // FDC Merkle roots per voting round (synced from Coston2)
    69‚Üí    mapping(uint256 votingRound => bytes32 merkleRoot) public fdcRoots;
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí    // Private balances
    72‚Üí    mapping(address depositor => uint256 balance) private balances;
    73‚Üí    mapping(bytes32 txHash => bool processed) public processedTxHashes;
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí    event RootSynced(uint256 indexed votingRound, bytes32 merkleRoot);
    76‚Üí    event DepositCredited(address indexed depositor, uint256 amount, bytes32 indexed txHash);
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí    constructor(address _rootRelayer, address _depositAddress) {
    79‚Üí        rootRelayer = _rootRelayer;
    80‚Üí        depositAddress = _depositAddress;
    81‚Üí    }
    82‚Üí
    83‚Üí    /// @notice Sync an FDC Merkle root from Coston2 (called by root relayer)
    84‚Üí    function syncRoot(uint256 votingRound, bytes32 merkleRoot) external {
    85‚Üí        require(msg.sender == rootRelayer, "Unauthorized");
    86‚Üí        require(fdcRoots[votingRound] == bytes32(0), "Root already set");
    87‚Üí        fdcRoots[votingRound] = merkleRoot;
    88‚Üí        emit RootSynced(votingRound, merkleRoot);
    89‚Üí    }
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí    /// @notice Verify an FDC proof and credit the deposit -- fully trustless
    92‚Üí    /// @param merkleProof The Merkle proof nodes from the FDC DA layer
    93‚Üí    /// @param attestationType bytes32 "EVMTransaction"
    94‚Üí    /// @param sourceId bytes32 "testETH"
    95‚Üí    /// @param votingRound The FDC voting round
    96‚Üí    /// @param lowestUsedTimestamp Timestamp from attestation
    97‚Üí    /// @param txHash The Sepolia tx hash
    98‚Üí    /// @param blockNumber Source chain block number
    99‚Üí    /// @param timestamp Source chain block timestamp
   100‚Üí    /// @param sourceAddress Sender on Sepolia
   101‚Üí    /// @param receivingAddress Receiver on Sepolia
   102‚Üí    /// @param value Wei transferred
   103‚Üí    /// @param status 1 = success
   104‚Üí    function verifyAndCredit(
   105‚Üí        bytes32[] calldata merkleProof,
   106‚Üí        bytes32 attestationType,
   107‚Üí        bytes32 sourceId,
   108‚Üí        uint64 votingRound,
   109‚Üí        uint64 lowestUsedTimestamp,
   110‚Üí        bytes32 txHash,
   111‚Üí        uint64 blockNumber,
   112‚Üí        uint64 timestamp,
   113‚Üí        address sourceAddress,
   114‚Üí        address receivingAddress,
   115‚Üí        uint256 value,
   116‚Üí        uint8 status
   117‚Üí    ) external {
   118‚Üí        // 1. Reconstruct the Merkle leaf (hash of the response data)
   119‚Üí        bytes32 leaf = keccak256(abi.encode(
   120‚Üí            attestationType, sourceId, votingRound, lowestUsedTimestamp,
   121‚Üí            txHash, blockNumber, timestamp, sourceAddress,
   122‚Üí            receivingAddress, value, status
   123‚Üí        ));
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí        // 2. Verify Merkle proof against stored root
   126‚Üí        bytes32 root = fdcRoots[votingRound];
   127‚Üí        require(root != bytes32(0), "Root not synced for this round");
   128‚Üí        require(_verifyMerkleProof(merkleProof, root, leaf), "Invalid Merkle proof");
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí        // 3. Validate deposit semantics
   131‚Üí        require(status == 1, "Tx not successful");
   132‚Üí        require(receivingAddress == depositAddress, "Wrong receiver");
   133‚Üí        require(!processedTxHashes[txHash], "Already processed");
   134‚Üí        require(value > 0, "Zero value");
   135‚Üí
   136‚Üí        // 4. Credit balance
   137‚Üí        processedTxHashes[txHash] = true;
   138‚Üí        balances[sourceAddress] += value;
   139‚Üí
   140‚Üí        emit DepositCredited(sourceAddress, value, txHash);
   141‚Üí    }
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí    /// @notice Standard binary Merkle proof verification
   144‚Üí    function _verifyMerkleProof(
   145‚Üí        bytes32[] calldata proof,
   146‚Üí        bytes32 root,
   147‚Üí        bytes32 leaf
   148‚Üí    ) internal pure returns (bool) {
   149‚Üí        bytes32 computedHash = leaf;
   150‚Üí        for (uint256 i = 0; i < proof.length; i++) {
   151‚Üí            bytes32 proofElement = proof[i];
   152‚Üí            if (computedHash <= proofElement) {
   153‚Üí                computedHash = keccak256(abi.encodePacked(computedHash, proofElement));
   154‚Üí            } else {
   155‚Üí                computedHash = keccak256(abi.encodePacked(proofElement, computedHash));
   156‚Üí            }
   157‚Üí        }
   158‚Üí        return computedHash == root;
   159‚Üí    }
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí    function getBalance() external view returns (uint256) {
   162‚Üí        return balances[msg.sender];
   163‚Üí    }
   164‚Üí}
   165‚Üí```
   166‚Üí
   167‚Üí## Research Required
   168‚Üí
   169‚ÜíThe leaf reconstruction (`keccak256(abi.encode(...))`) must exactly match how FDC's `FdcVerification` contract constructs the leaf. This needs investigation:
   170‚Üí
   171‚Üí1. **Leaf encoding**: Read the `FdcVerification` source or the Flare FDC spec to understand exact leaf encoding. It may include the full `RequestBody` and `ResponseBody` structs (including events, input data), not just the flat fields above.
   172‚Üí
   173‚Üí2. **Merkle tree convention**: FDC may use a specific sorted/unsorted convention for internal nodes. The `_verifyMerkleProof` above uses sorted pairs (OpenZeppelin convention). FDC might differ.
   174‚Üí
   175‚Üí3. **Root source on Coston2**: The Merkle root is stored in the `Relay` contract. We need the exact function to read it (`getConfirmedMerkleRoot(votingRound)` or similar).
   176‚Üí
   177‚ÜíThese can be investigated by:
   178‚Üí- Reading the FdcVerification source code on Coston2 block explorer
   179‚Üí- Checking the Flare FDC documentation/spec
   180‚Üí- Testing with a known proof: compute the leaf ourselves and verify it produces the right root
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üí## TypeScript Backend Flow
   183‚Üí
   184‚Üí```typescript
   185‚Üí// Step 1-4: Same FDC attestation flow as Plan 1
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üí// Step 5: Sync Merkle root to Sapphire (if not already synced)
   188‚Üí//   Read root from Coston2 Relay contract for this voting round
   189‚Üí//   Call accounting.syncRoot(votingRound, root) on Sapphire
   190‚Üíconst relay = new ethers.Contract(RELAY_ADDRESS, RELAY_ABI, coston2Provider);
   191‚Üíconst root = await relay.getConfirmedMerkleRoot(votingRoundId);
   192‚Üíawait accounting.syncRoot(votingRoundId, root);
   193‚Üí
   194‚Üí// Step 6: Submit proof to Sapphire (contract verifies locally)
   195‚Üíawait accounting.verifyAndCredit(
   196‚Üí    proofData.proof,           // Merkle proof nodes
   197‚Üí    resp.attestationType,
   198‚Üí    resp.sourceId,
   199‚Üí    BigInt(resp.votingRound),
   200‚Üí    BigInt(resp.lowestUsedTimestamp),
   201‚Üí    resp.requestBody.transactionHash,
   202‚Üí    BigInt(body.blockNumber),
   203‚Üí    BigInt(body.timestamp),
   204‚Üí    body.sourceAddress,
   205‚Üí    body.receivingAddress,
   206‚Üí    BigInt(body.value),
   207‚Üí    Number(body.status)
   208‚Üí);
   209‚Üí```
   210‚Üí
   211‚Üí## What This Proves
   212‚Üí
   213‚Üí1. FDC Merkle proofs can be verified on any chain, not just Coston2
   214‚Üí2. Sapphire can independently verify deposit proofs (no trusted relayer for proof data)
   215‚Üí3. Root relay is the only trusted component (cannot forge proofs, only censor)
   216‚Üí4. Equivalent to FlexVaults' model: ShoyuBashi provides trusted block hashes -> ProvethVerifier verifies proofs. Here: root relayer provides trusted Merkle roots -> Sapphire verifies FDC proofs.
   217‚Üí
   218‚Üí## Limitations
   219‚Üí
   220‚Üí- Leaf encoding must exactly match FDC's internal format (requires research)
   221‚Üí- Root relayer can censor (delay roots) but cannot forge deposits
   222‚Üí- No ERC-20 support in PoC
   223‚Üí- Simplified proof struct (may need events/input for full leaf hash)
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí## Complexity
   226‚Üí
   227‚Üí- ~120 lines Solidity (vs ~1000+ in FlexVaults, but much simpler logic)
   228‚Üí- ~250 lines TypeScript
   229‚Üí- Root relay is the only infrastructure (vs ROFL TEE + oracle + Hashi)
   230‚Üí
   231‚Üí## Comparison with Plan 1
   232‚Üí
   233‚Üí| Aspect | Plan 1 (Trusted Relayer) | Plan 2 (Merkle on Sapphire) |
   234‚Üí|---|---|---|
   235‚Üí| **Implementation effort** | Low (~2-3 hours) | Medium (~4-6 hours + research) |
   236‚Üí| **Trust model** | Relayer trusted for accuracy | Relayer only trusted for root freshness |
   237‚Üí| **Can relayer forge deposits?** | Yes (it submits raw data) | No (must have valid Merkle proof) |
   238‚Üí| **Research needed** | None | FDC leaf encoding format |
   239‚Üí| **Solidity complexity** | ~80 lines, trivial | ~120 lines, needs exact FDC encoding |
   240‚Üí| **Closest to FlexVaults model** | Yes (trusted backend) | Yes (trustless proofs, trusted root source) |
   241‚Üí| **Production path** | Add ROFL TEE for relayer | Add decentralized root relay |
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí## Recommendation
   244‚Üí
   245‚ÜíStart with Plan 1 for fast validation that FDC provides all necessary data. Then attempt Plan 2 to prove the stronger trustless property. Plan 1 can be completed in a single session; Plan 2 may need iteration to match FDC's exact leaf encoding.
   246‚Üí
