    42‚ÜíPython Backend (FastAPI in ROFL TEE)
    43‚Üí‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    44‚Üí‚îÇ  DepositListener  ‚Äî polls source chains for deposits to deposit addr ‚îÇ
    45‚Üí‚îÇ  WithdrawalProcessor ‚Äî polls for pending withdrawals, resolves/bcasts‚îÇ
    46‚Üí‚îÇ  ProofGenerator   ‚Äî builds tx + receipt Merkle Patricia Trie proofs  ‚îÇ
    47‚Üí‚îÇ  AccountingContractService ‚Äî submits txs to Accounting via ROFL      ‚îÇ
    48‚Üí‚îÇ  RoflAppdClient   ‚Äî ROFL daemon client (key gen, tx sign+submit)     ‚îÇ
    49‚Üí‚îÇ  FastAPI routes    ‚Äî REST API at /v1/accounting/*                     ‚îÇ
    50‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    51‚Üí```
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí## Smart Contracts
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí### Accounting.sol (main contract)
    56‚Üí
    57‚ÜíThe central ledger. Manages `mapping(address => mapping(bytes32 tokenId => uint256))` balances. Inherits `EIP712SignatureVerifier` and `EVMSignerAndVerifier`.
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí**Deposit flow:**
    60‚Üí- `creditEVMDeposit(userAddress, tokenId, txProof, receiptProof)` ‚Äî verifies both the transaction and receipt inclusion proofs via `ProvethVerifier`, decodes the raw EVM transaction (supports Legacy, EIP-2930, EIP-1559), verifies the block hash via ShoyuBashi oracle, validates sender/recipient/amount, and credits the user's balance.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí**Fund locking:**
    63‚Üí- `createLock(user, service, tokenId, amount, expiry, signature)` ‚Äî moves funds from balance to a time-locked escrow. Max 10 active locks per user.
    64‚Üí- `modifyLock(user, lockId, amount, newExpiry, signature)` ‚Äî add funds or extend expiry on an existing lock.
    65‚Üí- `transferFromLock(user, to, lockId, amount, signature)` ‚Äî the *service* signs to authorize transferring locked funds to a recipient.
    66‚Üí- `unlockSingleLock(user, lockId)` / `unlockAllExpiredLocks(user)` ‚Äî reclaim expired locks.
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí**Transfers:**
    69‚Üí- `transferBalance(user, to, tokenId, amount, signature)` ‚Äî off-chain-signed peer-to-peer transfer within the ledger.
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí**Withdrawal flow:**
    72‚Üí- `requestWithdrawal(user, tokenId, amount, nonce, signature)` ‚Äî debits balance, records a `WithdrawalRequest` with a chain-specific nonce.
    73‚Üí- `resolveWithdrawal(index)` ‚Äî generates a signed EVM transaction (via Sapphire's `EIP155Signer` precompile) for the destination chain. Idempotent ‚Äî can be called multiple times to retry broadcast.
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**Token registry:**
    76‚Üí- `setTokenInfo(TokenInfo)` ‚Äî owner registers supported tokens.
    77‚Üí- `getTokenId(TokenInfo)` ‚Äî deterministic `keccak256(abi.encode(tokenType, data))`.
    78‚Üí- Token types: `NativeEVM` (32 bytes: chainId) or `ERC20` (52 bytes: chainId + address).
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí### EVMSignerAndVerifier.sol
    81‚Üí
    82‚ÜíHandles the cryptographic heavy lifting:
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí- **Transaction decoding** ‚Äî `decodeEVMTransaction()` supports Legacy (>= 0xc0), EIP-2930 (type 1), and EIP-1559 (type 2) transactions. Recovers sender via ECDSA.
    85‚Üí- **Transaction signing** ‚Äî `generateNativeTransfer()` and `generateERC20Transfer()` use Sapphire's `EIP155Signer.sign()` precompile with a secret key generated at deployment via `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()`.
    86‚Üí- **Block hash verification** ‚Äî `verifyBlockHash()` queries `ShoyuBashi.getUnanimousHash(chainId, blockNumber)`.
    87‚Üí- **Receipt decoding** ‚Äî `decodeEVMTxReceipt()` extracts status and gas used.
    88‚Üí- **Nonce management** ‚Äî per-chain nonces for withdrawal transactions.
    89‚Üí- **Gas price management** ‚Äî `setGasPrice(chainId, gasPrice)` ‚Äî owner-only, must be set before generating withdrawal txs.
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí### EIP712SignatureVerifier.sol
    92‚Üí
    93‚ÜíTyped data signing for all user operations:
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí| Operation | Type Hash | Signer |
    96‚Üí|---|---|---|
    97‚Üí| `Withdraw` | `Withdraw(address userAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount,uint256 nonce)` | User |
    98‚Üí| `Lock` | `Lock(address userAddress,address serviceAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount,uint256 expiry)` | User |
    99‚Üí| `Transfer` | `Transfer(address userAddress,address toAddress,bytes32 tokenId,uint256 amount)` | User |
   100‚Üí| `TransferLocked` | `TransferLocked(address userAddress,address toAddress,uint256 lockId,uint256 amount)` | Service |
   101‚Üí| `ModifyLock` | `ModifyLock(address userAddress,uint256 lockId,uint256 amount,uint256 newExpiry)` | User |
   102‚Üí
   103‚ÜíDomain: `name="AccountingModule"`, `version="1"`. Signatures are single-use (tracked in `usedSignatures` mapping). Withdrawals use a per-user nonce instead.
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí### ProvethVerifier.sol
   106‚Üí
   107‚ÜíMerkle Patricia Trie proof verification for both transactions and receipts. Validates proofs against `transactionsRoot` and `receiptsRoot` in the block header.
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí### ShoyuBashi (external ‚Äî Hashi)
   110‚Üí
   111‚ÜíMulti-oracle block hash consensus system. The `Accounting` contract calls `shoyuBashi.getUnanimousHash(chainId, blockNumber)` to verify that the block hash in a deposit proof is legitimate. The ROFL Header Oracle (see [rofl-header-oracle.md](./rofl-header-oracle.md)) feeds block hashes into the `ROFLAdapter`, which is one of ShoyuBashi's configured adapters.
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí## Python Backend
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí### Tech Stack
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí- **FastAPI** (uvicorn) ‚Äî REST API
   118‚Üí- **web3.py** ‚Äî blockchain interaction
   119‚Üí- **oasis-rofl-client** ‚Äî ROFL daemon communication
   120‚Üí- **rlp** / **trie** (HexaryTrie) ‚Äî Merkle Patricia Trie proof generation
   121‚Üí- **cbor2** ‚Äî ROFL response decoding
   122‚Üí- Runs in Docker inside a ROFL TEE container (TDX)
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí### Key Services
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí**DepositListener** (`src/services/deposit_listener.py`)
   127‚Üí- Polls configured source chains for incoming transfers to the deposit address (both native and ERC-20 `Transfer` events).
   128‚Üí- Waits for the block hash to appear in the ROFLAdapter on Sapphire (via `getHash(chainId, blockNumber)`).
   129‚Üí- Generates Merkle Patricia Trie proofs (tx proof + receipt proof) using `debug_getRawBlock` and `debug_getRawReceipts` RPCs.
   130‚Üí- Submits `creditEVMDeposit()` to the Accounting contract via ROFL.
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí**WithdrawalProcessor** (`src/services/withdrawal_processor.py`)
   133‚Üí- Polls for pending `WithdrawalRequest` entries in the Accounting contract.
   134‚Üí- Calls `resolveWithdrawal(index)` to get a signed transaction from the contract.
   135‚Üí- Broadcasts the signed tx to the destination chain.
   136‚Üí- Includes a catch-up mechanism that compares contract nonces vs destination chain nonces to find and re-broadcast missing withdrawals.
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí**ProofGenerator** (`src/services/proof_generator.py`)
   139‚Üí- Builds both transaction and receipt Merkle Patricia Trie inclusion proofs.
   140‚Üí- Uses `debug_getRawBlock` to get raw block data and reconstruct the trie.
   141‚Üí- Uses `debug_getRawReceipts` for receipt proofs.
   142‚Üí- Requires archive node access with debug API enabled.
   143‚Üí
   144‚Üí**AccountingContractService** (`src/services/accounting_contract.py`)
   145‚Üí- Wraps all contract interactions: deposits, locks, transfers, withdrawals.
   146‚Üí- Submits transactions via the `RoflAppdClient`.
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí**RoflAppdClient** (`src/clients/rofl.py`)
   149‚Üí- Singleton wrapper around `oasis-rofl-client`.
   150‚Üí- `get_keypair(key_id)` ‚Äî generates secp256k1 keys via ROFL daemon.
   151‚Üí- `submit_tx(tx)` ‚Äî signs and submits transactions, decodes CBOR responses, detects reverts by decoding error selectors.
   152‚Üí
   153‚Üí### REST API
   154‚Üí
   155‚ÜíAll routes under `/v1/accounting/`:
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí| Method | Endpoint | Description |
   158‚Üí|---|---|---|
   159‚Üí| POST | `/quote/deposit` | Get deposit instructions (address, tx data) |
   160‚Üí| POST | `/deposits` | Submit deposit inclusion proof |
   161‚Üí| POST | `/funds/lock` | Lock funds for a service |
   162‚Üí| POST | `/funds/modify-lock` | Modify an existing lock |
   163‚Üí| POST | `/funds/transfer` | Transfer between users |
   164‚Üí| POST | `/funds/transfer-locked` | Transfer from locked funds (service-signed) |
   165‚Üí| POST | `/funds/unlock` | Unlock expired lock |
   166‚Üí| POST | `/funds/unlock-all-expired` | Unlock all expired locks |
   167‚Üí| POST | `/withdrawals` | Request withdrawal |
   168‚Üí| GET | `/balances/{user}/{tokenId}` | Get user balance |
   169‚Üí| POST | `/balances/batch` | Get multiple balances |
   170‚Üí| GET | `/locks/{user}` | Get user's active locks |
   171‚Üí| GET | `/locks/{user}/expired` | Get expired locks |
   172‚Üí| GET | `/tokens/{tokenId}` | Get token info |
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí### Configuration
   175‚Üí
   176‚ÜíEnvironment variables (loaded via `src/config/__init__.py`):
   177‚Üí
   178‚Üí| Variable | Description |
   179‚Üí|---|---|
   180‚Üí| `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` | Accounting contract on Sapphire |
   181‚Üí| `ROFL_ADAPTER_ADDRESS` | ROFLAdapter for block hash lookups |
   182‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_RPC_URL` | Sapphire RPC endpoint |
   183‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_CHAIN_ID` | Sapphire chain ID |
   184‚Üí| `ALCHEMY_API_KEY` | Used to construct source chain RPC URLs |
   185‚Üí| `DEPOSIT_POLL_INTERVAL` | Seconds between deposit checks |
   186‚Üí
   187‚ÜíCurrently configured for **Base Sepolia** (chain ID 84532) as the source chain, with USDC ERC-20 support.
   188‚Üí
   189‚Üí## Deployment
   190‚Üí
   191‚Üí- **ROFL TEE:** TDX container, 1 CPU, 1GB RAM, 8GB persistent disk
   192‚Üí- **Docker:** Multi-stage build (see `Dockerfile`)
   193‚Üí- **Secrets:** Encrypted in `rofl.yaml` via ROFL secrets management
   194‚Üí- **Solidity tooling:** Hardhat with Sapphire plugin, deployed via `npx hardhat deploy --shoyubashi <addr>`
   195‚Üí
   196‚Üí## Security Model
   197‚Üí
   198‚Üí1. **Deposit verification** ‚Äî tx + receipt Merkle Patricia Trie proofs verified on-chain by ProvethVerifier, block hash consensus via ShoyuBashi (multi-oracle).
   199‚Üí2. **User authorization** ‚Äî all balance-affecting operations require EIP-712 typed data signatures; signatures are single-use.
   200‚Üí3. **Withdrawal security** ‚Äî private key for destination chain signing lives only in the Sapphire contract (generated via `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()`). Resolution requires a block delay to prevent simulation attacks.
   201‚Üí4. **TEE isolation** ‚Äî backend runs inside ROFL TDX enclave. ROFL daemon handles key derivation and transaction signing.
   202‚Üí
   203‚Üí## Relevance to Flare FDC PoC
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí| FlexVaults | Flare FDC PoC |
   206‚Üí|---|---|
   207‚Üí| Verifies source chain txs via Merkle Patricia Trie proofs (ProvethVerifier) | Verifies Sepolia txs via FDC attestation + Merkle proof against attestation root |
   208‚Üí| Block hash trust via ShoyuBashi (multi-oracle consensus) | Block/tx trust via FDC attestation providers (decentralized voting) |
   209‚Üí| Full tx decoding on-chain (Legacy, EIP-2930, EIP-1559) | Verifies specific tx fields via FDC response structure |
   210‚Üí| Proof generation uses `debug_getRawBlock` + HexaryTrie | Proof generation handled by FDC protocol / attestation clients |
   211‚Üí| Balances live on Sapphire (private) | Verification result lives on Coston2 (public) |
   212‚Üí| Two-phase withdrawal (request -> resolve -> broadcast) | Single-step attestation verification |
   213‚Üí
   214‚ÜíThe key shared concept is **transaction inclusion proofs**: both systems need to prove that a specific transaction was included in a specific block on the source chain, and both verify this against a trusted block hash. FlexVaults does the Merkle proof verification itself on-chain, while the Flare FDC delegates proof verification to a network of attestation providers.
   215‚Üí

data.prompt:
Design an implementation plan for adding encumbered wallets (deposit addresses) to the FDC trusted relayer PoC, following the FlexVaults pattern but simplified for a PoC.

## Current State

The current FdcAccounting.sol (at fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol) is a simple contract:
- `authorizedRelayer` (immutable address)
- `balances` mapping (private)
- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

The current accounting-demo.ts flow:
- Step 0: Send ETH to self on Sepolia
- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

Hardhat config uses solidity 0.8.24 with @oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat plugin.

## FlexVaults Pattern (what we want to mimic, simplified)

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain
4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**

content.content:
1‚Üí## ADDED Requirements
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí### Requirement: Authorized relayer credit
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe `FdcAccounting` contract SHALL accept deposit credits only from the authorized relayer address set at construction time. Any call to `creditDeposit` from a non-relayer address MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer credits a deposit
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` with a valid tx hash, depositor address, and non-zero value
    10‚Üí- **THEN** the contract records the deposit, increments the depositor's balance by `value`, and emits `DepositCredited(depositor, value, txHash)`
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí#### Scenario: Non-relayer attempts credit
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí- **WHEN** any address other than the authorized relayer calls `creditDeposit`
    15‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí### Requirement: Double-credit prevention
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíThe contract SHALL track processed Sepolia transaction hashes and reject any attempt to credit the same tx hash twice.
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí#### Scenario: First credit for a tx hash
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has not been processed before
    24‚Üí- **THEN** the deposit is credited and the tx hash is marked as processed
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí#### Scenario: Duplicate credit attempt
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with a tx hash that has already been processed
    29‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `AlreadyProcessed(txHash)`
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí### Requirement: Zero-value rejection
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThe contract SHALL reject deposits with zero value to prevent meaningless state changes.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí#### Scenario: Zero-value deposit
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí- **WHEN** the relayer calls `creditDeposit` with `value = 0`
    38‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `ZeroValue()`
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### Requirement: Private balance storage
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíDepositor balances SHALL be stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private mapping). Balances MUST NOT be readable by arbitrary external observers.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí#### Scenario: Depositor queries own balance
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí- **WHEN** a depositor calls `getBalance()` from their own address
    47‚Üí- **THEN** the contract returns that depositor's current balance
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí#### Scenario: Relayer queries any balance
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí- **WHEN** the authorized relayer calls `getBalanceOf(user)`
    52‚Üí- **THEN** the contract returns the specified user's balance
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí#### Scenario: Unauthorized balance query
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí- **WHEN** a non-relayer address calls `getBalanceOf(user)` for another user
    57‚Üí- **THEN** the transaction MUST revert with `Unauthorized()`
    58‚Üí

- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile

- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance

   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx

     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)

content.content:
1‚Üí## Context
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThe existing `src/poc.ts` demonstrates FDC attestation end-to-end: prepare request, submit to Coston2, wait for proof, verify on-chain. This design extends that flow to relay verified deposit data to a Sapphire accounting contract, mirroring FlexVaults' architecture with dramatically less infrastructure.
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe codebase uses TypeScript (strict ESM), ethers.js v6, and runs via tsx. There are no existing Solidity contracts or Hardhat tooling in the project.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Goals / Non-Goals
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí**Goals:**
    10‚Üí- Demonstrate FDC-verified cross-chain deposit accounting on Sapphire with private balances
    11‚Üí- Keep the relayer simple ‚Äî single TypeScript entry point, no queue or persistence
    12‚Üí- Reuse existing FDC attestation logic from `src/poc.ts` where possible
    13‚Üí- Provide a self-contained demo that deploys the contract and runs the full flow
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí**Non-Goals:**
    16‚Üí- Production relayer (no retries, no event watching, no queue)
    17‚Üí- ROFL TEE integration for the relayer (plain EOA signer for PoC)
    18‚Üí- ERC-20 token support (native ETH only)
    19‚Üí- Withdrawals, transfers, or fund locking
    20‚Üí- Mainnet deployment or gas optimization
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí## Decisions
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí### 1. Separate `contracts/` subdirectory with Hardhat
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí**Decision**: Solidity compilation via Hardhat in `fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/`, separate from the tsx-based TypeScript runtime.
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí**Rationale**: Hardhat handles Solidity compilation, ABI generation, and deployment scripts cleanly. Keeping it in a subdirectory avoids polluting the root `package.json` with Solidity tooling.
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Inline ABI as a JSON constant in TypeScript. Rejected because it makes the contract source non-compilable and harder to verify/modify.
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí### 2. Single-file relayer at `src/accounting-demo.ts`
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí**Decision**: One TypeScript file orchestrates the full flow (deploy ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí relay ‚Üí query).
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí**Rationale**: Matches the project's existing pattern (`src/poc.ts` is single-file). For a PoC, a linear script is clearer than a modular architecture.
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Alternative considered**: Extract shared FDC logic into a library module. Worth doing if the codebase grows, but premature for two files.
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### 3. Sapphire provider wrapping with `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime`
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí**Decision**: Wrap the ethers.js provider with `sapphire.wrap()` for automatic transaction encryption.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**Rationale**: This is the standard Sapphire integration pattern. It encrypts calldata so balance queries and deposits stay confidential on-chain.
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí### 4. Contract deploys fresh each run (no address persistence)
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí**Decision**: The demo script deploys `FdcAccounting` on each run rather than persisting a contract address.
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí**Rationale**: Simplifies the PoC ‚Äî no state file or env var management for contract addresses. The demo is self-contained. Users can easily modify to connect to an existing deployment.
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí### 5. Double-credit prevention via tx hash mapping
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí**Decision**: `processedTxHashes` mapping in the contract prevents the same Sepolia tx from being credited twice.
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí**Rationale**: Essential correctness property. Even though the PoC relayer only runs once, the contract must be safe against replays for any real usage.
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí## Risks / Trade-offs
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí- **[Trusted relayer is a single point of trust]** ‚Üí Acceptable for PoC. In production, wrap in ROFL TEE or use multisig. The contract's `onlyRelayer` modifier is already designed for a single authorized address, which maps cleanly to a ROFL app address.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí- **[FDC proof verified on Coston2, not on Sapphire]** ‚Üí The relayer bridges two separate chains. The Sapphire contract trusts the relayer's attestation. This is architecturally identical to FlexVaults (ROFL backend verifies proof, then writes to Sapphire).
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí- **[Sapphire testnet availability]** ‚Üí Sapphire testnet may have downtime. No mitigation needed for a PoC.
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí- **[Hardhat adds dependency weight]** ‚Üí Only needed in `contracts/` subdirectory. Does not affect the tsx runtime. Could use solc directly but Hardhat provides better DX for deployment.
    67‚Üí

Links: [{"title":"Oasis Sapphire","url":"https://oasis.net/sapphire"},{"title":"Build Secure dApps with Oasis Smart Privacy","url":"https://oasisprotocol.org/build"},{"title":"Sapphire 101: A Technical Workshop For Blockchain Devs Part 3 | Coinmonks","url":"https://medium.REDACTED"},{"title":"contracts: Added EIP-155 signer and extended EthereumUtils by CedarMist ¬∑ Pull Request #154 ¬∑ oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime","url":"https://github.com/oasisprotocol/sapphire-paratime/pull/154"},{"title":"Smart Privacy for Better dApps and Web3 Applications","url":"https://oasis.net/smart-privacy"},{"title":"@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts - npm","url":"https://www.npmjs.com/package/@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts"},{"title":"Gasless Transactions | Oasis Documentation","url":"https://docs.oasis.io/build/sapphire/develop/gasless/"},{"title":"Unveiling Oasis Protocol‚Äôs Sapphire: Confidential Smart Contracts for the Modern Blockchain Era | by Manav | caerlower.eth | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@caerlower/unveiling-oasis-protocols-sapphire-confidential-smart-contracts-for-the-modern-blockchain-era-41a30b20bff1"},{"title":"Oasis","url":"https://oasisprotocol.org/"},{"title":"Oasis Sapphire: Understanding confidential smart contracts - Chainstack","url":"https://docs.chainstack.com/docs/oasis-sapphire-tutorial-understanding-confidential-smart-contracts-with-oasis-sapphire"}]

I found comprehensive information about the Oasis Protocol Sapphire contracts and the components you mentioned. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

The @oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts is a Solidity smart contract library for confidential contract development. The latest version is 0.2.14, last published 5 months ago, and can be installed via npm with `npm i @oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts`.

## Key Components

**EthereumUtils and generateKeypair:**
EthereumUtils.generateKeypair() generates an Ethereum keypair that returns both an address and secret.

**EIP155Signer:**
The EIP155Signer allows contracts to sign and encode Ethereum compatible EIP-155 transactions. The EIP155Signer library bundled with the @oasisprotocol/sapphire-contract package provides a helper function that returns a raw, RLP-encoded, signed transaction ready to be broadcast.

## Usage Example

A typical implementation uses EthereumUtils.generateKeypair() to generate a keypair, then calls EIP155Signer.sign() with the signer address, secret, and transaction details to produce a signed transaction.

## Documentation

The generated API reference is hosted at api.docs.oasis.io.

This library is actively maintained and used for implementing gasless transactions and confidential smart contract functionality on the Oasis Sapphire network.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire

- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)

3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?

content.content:
// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
pragma solidity ^0.8.0;

/**
 * @title Sapphire
 * @notice This library provides a number of convenient wrappers for
 * cryptographic operations such as the x25519 key derivation, Deoxys-II-based
 * encryption and decryption, signing key generation, message digest signing and
 * verification, gas padding and hashing.
 *
 * Most of the mentioned functions are implemented as Sapphire's precompiles and
 * are cheap to call.
 *
 * #### Calling Precompiles Manually
 *
 * You can override the wrappers and call Sapphire precompiles by dispatching
 * calls to specific well-known contract addresses, as described below. The
 * __Precompile address__ section of each function will show you the address
 * of the corresponding precompile.
 *
 * Input parameters should be packed into a contiguous memory region with each
 * chunk of data padded to 32 bytes as usual. The recommended way to construct
 * parameter byte sequences in Solidity is with `abi.encode` and `abi.decode`,
 * which will transparently handle things like putting `bytes` lengths in the
 * correct position.
 */
library Sapphire {
    // Oasis-specific, confidential precompiles
    address internal constant RANDOM_BYTES =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000001;
    address internal constant DERIVE_KEY =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000002;
    address internal constant ENCRYPT =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000003;
    address internal constant DECRYPT =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000004;
    address internal constant GENERATE_SIGNING_KEYPAIR =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000005;
    address internal constant SIGN_DIGEST =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000006;
    address internal constant VERIFY_DIGEST =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000007;
    address internal constant CURVE25519_PUBLIC_KEY =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000008;
    address internal constant GAS_USED =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000009;
    address internal constant PAD_GAS =
        0x010000000000000000000000000000000000000a;

    // Oasis-specific, general precompiles
    address internal constant SHA512_256 =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000101;
    address internal constant SHA512 =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000102;
    address internal constant SHA384 =
        0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000104;

    type Curve25519PublicKey is bytes32;
    type Curve25519SecretKey is bytes32;

    enum SigningAlg {
        /// Ed25519 signature over the provided message using SHA-512/265 with a domain separator.
        /// Can be used to sign transactions for the Oasis consensus layer and SDK paratimes.
        Ed25519Oasis,
        /// Ed25519 signature over the provided message.
        Ed25519Pure,
        /// Ed25519 signature over the provided prehashed SHA-512 digest.
        Ed25519PrehashedSha512,
        /// Secp256k1 signature over the provided message using SHA-512/256 with a domain separator.
        /// Can be used to sign transactions for the Oasis consensus layer and SDK paratimes.
        Secp256k1Oasis,
        /// Secp256k1 over the provided Keccak256 digest.
        /// Can be used to sign transactions for Ethereum-compatible networks.
        Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256,
        /// Secp256k1 signature over the provided SHA-256 digest.
        Secp256k1PrehashedSha256,
        /// Sr25519 signature over the provided message.
        Sr25519,
        /// Secp256r1 signature over the provided SHA-256 digest.
        Secp256r1PrehashedSha256,
        /// Secp384r1 signature over the provided SHA-384 digest.
        Secp384r1PrehashedSha384
    }

    /**
     * @notice Generate `num_bytes` pseudo-random bytes, with an optional
     * personalization string (`pers`) added into the hashing algorithm to
     * increase domain separation when needed.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000001`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * 10,000 minimum plus 240 per output word plus 60 per word of the
     * personalization string.
     *
     * #### Implementation details
     *
     * The mode (e.g. simulation or "view call" vs transaction execution) is fed
     * to TupleHash (among other block-dependent components) to derive the "key
     * id", which is then used to derive a per-block VRF key from
     * epoch-ephemeral entropy (using KMAC256 and cSHAKE) so a different key
     * id will result in a unique per-block VRF key. This per-block VRF key is
     * then used to create the per-block root RNG which is then used to derive
     * domain-separated (using Merlin transcripts) per-transaction random RNGs
     * which are then exposed via this precompile. The KMAC, cSHAKE and
     * TupleHash algorithms are SHA-3 derived functions defined in [NIST
     * Special Publication 800-185](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/specialpublications/nist.sp.800-185.pdf).
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * bytes memory randomPad = Sapphire.randomBytes(64, "");
     * ```
     *
     * @param numBytes The number of bytes to return.
     * @param pers An optional personalization string to increase domain
     *        separation.
     * @return The random bytes. If the number of bytes requested is too large
     *         (over 1024), a smaller amount (1024) will be returned.
     */
    function randomBytes(uint256 numBytes, bytes memory pers)
        internal
        view
        returns (bytes memory)
    {
        (bool success, bytes memory entropy) = RANDOM_BYTES.staticcall(
            abi.encode(numBytes, pers)
        );
        require(success, "randomBytes: failed");
        return entropy;
    }

    /**
     * @notice Generates a Curve25519 keypair.
     * @param pers An optional personalization string used to add domain
     * separation.
     * @return pk The Curve25519 public key. Useful for key exchange.
     * @return sk The Curve25519 secret key. Pairs well with
     * [deriveSymmetricKey](#derivesymmetrickey).
     */
    function generateCurve25519KeyPair(bytes memory pers)
        internal
        view
        returns (Curve25519PublicKey pk, Curve25519SecretKey sk)
    {
        bytes memory scalar = randomBytes(32, pers);
        // Twiddle some bits, as per RFC 7748 ¬ß5.
        scalar[0] &= 0xf8; // Make it a multiple of 8 to avoid small subgroup attacks.
        scalar[31] &= 0x7f; // Clamp to < 2^255 - 19
        scalar[31] |= 0x40; // Clamp to >= 2^254
        (bool success, bytes memory pkBytes) = CURVE25519_PUBLIC_KEY.staticcall(
            scalar
        );
        require(success, "gen curve25519 pk: failed");
        return (
            Curve25519PublicKey.wrap(bytes32(pkBytes)),
            Curve25519SecretKey.wrap(bytes32(scalar))
        );
    }

    /**
     * @notice Derive a symmetric key from a pair of keys using x25519.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000002`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * 100,000
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * bytes32 publicKey = ... ;
     * bytes32 privateKey = ... ;
     * bytes32 symmetric = Sapphire.deriveSymmetricKey(publicKey, privateKey);
     * ```
     *
     * @param peerPublicKey The peer's public key.
     * @param secretKey Your secret key.
     * @return A derived symmetric key.
     */
    function deriveSymmetricKey(
        Curve25519PublicKey peerPublicKey,
        Curve25519SecretKey secretKey
    ) internal view returns (bytes32) {
        (bool success, bytes memory symmetric) = DERIVE_KEY.staticcall(
            abi.encode(peerPublicKey, secretKey)
        );
        require(success, "deriveSymmetricKey: failed");
        return bytes32(symmetric);
    }

    /**
     * @notice Encrypt and authenticate the plaintext and additional data using
     * DeoxysII.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000003`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * 50,000 minimum plus 100 per word of input
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * bytes32 key = ... ;
     * bytes32 nonce = ... ;
     * bytes memory text = "plain text";
     * bytes memory ad = "additional data";
     * bytes memory encrypted = Sapphire.encrypt(key, nonce, text, ad);
     * bytes memory decrypted = Sapphire.decrypt(key, nonce, encrypted, ad);
     * ```
     *
     * @param key The key to use for encryption.
     * @param nonce The nonce. Note that only the first 15 bytes of this
     * parameter are used.
     * @param plaintext The plaintext to encrypt and authenticate.
     * @param additionalData The additional data to authenticate.
     * @return The ciphertext with appended auth tag.
     */
    function encrypt(
        bytes32 key,
        bytes32 nonce,
        bytes memory plaintext,
        bytes memory additionalData
    ) internal view returns (bytes memory) {
        (bool success, bytes memory ciphertext) = ENCRYPT.staticcall(
            abi.encode(key, nonce, plaintext, additionalData)
        );
        require(success, "encrypt: failed");
        return ciphertext;
    }

    /**
     * @notice Decrypt and authenticate the ciphertext and additional data using
     * DeoxysII. Reverts if the auth tag is incorrect.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000004`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * 50,000 minimum plus 100 per word of input
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * bytes32 key = ... ;
     * bytes32 nonce = ... ;
     * bytes memory text = "plain text";
     * bytes memory ad = "additional data";
     * bytes memory encrypted = Sapphire.encrypt(key, nonce, text, ad);
     * bytes memory decrypted = Sapphire.decrypt(key, nonce, encrypted, ad);
     * ```
     *
     * @param key The key to use for decryption.
     * @param nonce The nonce. Note that only the first 15 bytes of this
     * parameter are used.
     * @param ciphertext The ciphertext with tag to decrypt and authenticate.
     * @param additionalData The additional data to authenticate against the
     * ciphertext.
     * @return The original plaintext.
     */
    function decrypt(
        bytes32 key,
        bytes32 nonce,
        bytes memory ciphertext,
        bytes memory additionalData
    ) internal view returns (bytes memory) {
        (bool success, bytes memory plaintext) = DECRYPT.staticcall(
            abi.encode(key, nonce, ciphertext, additionalData)
        );
        require(success, "decrypt: failed");
        return plaintext;
    }

    /**
     * @notice Generate a public/private key pair using the specified method and
     * seed. The available methods are items in the
     * [`Sapphire.SigningAlg`](#signingalg) enum. Note, however, that the
     * generation method ignores subvariants, so all three Ed25519-based are
     * equivalent, and all Secp256k1 & Secp256r1 based methods are equivalent.
     * Sr25519 is not available and will return an error.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000005`
     *
     * #### Gas Cost
     *
     * ##### Ed25519: 1,000 gas
     *
     * - `0` (`Ed25519Oasis`)
     * - `1` (`Ed25519Pure`)
     * - `2` (`Ed25519PrehashedSha512`)
     *
     * ##### Secp256k1: 1,500 gas.
     * - `3` (`Secp256k1Oasis`)
     * - `4` (`Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256`)
     * - `5` (`Secp256k1PrehashedSha256`)
     *
     * ##### Secp256r1: 4,000 gas
     * - `7` (`Secp256r1PrehashedSha256`)
     *
     * ##### Secp384r1: 18,000 gas
     * - `8` (`Secp384r1PrehashedSha384`)
     *
     * #### Key Formats
     *
     * ##### Ed25519
     *
     * Public key: 32 bytes
     * Secret key: 32 bytes
     *
     * ##### Secp256k1 & Secp256r1
     *
     * Public key: 33 bytes, compressed format (`0x02` or `0x03` prefix, then 32
     * byte X coordinate).
     * Secret key: 32 bytes
     *
     * ##### Secp384r1
     *
     * Public key: 49 bytes, compressed format (`0x02` or `0x03` prefix, then 48
     * byte X coordinate).
     * Secret key: 48 bytes
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * bytes memory seed = hex"0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef";
     * bytes memory publicKey;
     * bytes memory privateKey;
     * (publicKey, privateKey) = Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Ed25519Pure, seed);
     * ```
     *
     * @param alg The signing alg for which to generate a keypair.
     * @param seed The seed to use for generating the key pair. You can use the
     * `randomBytes` method if you don't already have a seed.
     * @return publicKey The public part of the keypair.
     * @return secretKey The secret part of the keypair.
     */
    function generateSigningKeyPair(SigningAlg alg, bytes memory seed)
        internal
        view
        returns (bytes memory publicKey, bytes memory secretKey)
    {
        (bool success, bytes memory keypair) = GENERATE_SIGNING_KEYPAIR
            .staticcall(abi.encode(alg, seed));
        require(success, "gen signing keypair: failed");
        return abi.decode(keypair, (bytes, bytes));
    }

    /**
     * @notice Sign a message within the provided context using the specified
     * algorithm, and return the signature. The `contextOrHash` and
     * `message` parameters change in meaning slightly depending on the algorithm
     * requested:
     *
     * For algorithms that use domain-separation contexts:
     * - Ed25519Oasis and Secp256k1Oasis: Pass the domain separator context string as
     *   `contextOrHash` and the message to sign as `message`.
     *
     * For algorithms that use pre-computed hashes:
     * - Ed25519PrehashedSha512: Pass the SHA-512 hash (64 bytes) as `contextOrHash`
     *   and set `message` to empty.
     * - Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256: Pass the Keccak256 hash (32 bytes) as `contextOrHash`
     *   and set `message` to empty. The hash should be computed as `bytes memory hash = abi.encodePacked(keccak256(message))`.
     * - Secp256k1PrehashedSha256: Pass the SHA-256 hash (32 bytes) as `contextOrHash`
     *   and set `message` to empty.
     * - Secp256r1PrehashedSha256: Pass the SHA-256 hash (32 bytes) as `contextOrHash`
     *   and set `message` to empty.
     * - Secp384r1PrehashedSha384: Pass the SHA-384 hash (48 bytes) as `contextOrHash`
     *   and set `message` to empty.
     *
     * For Sr25519 signatures (for Substrate compatibility):
     * - Sr25519: You MUST pass "substrate" as the `contextOrHash` parameter to ensure
     *   compatibility with Substrate off-chain signing that uses the `{ withType: true }`
     *   parameter. Pass the message to sign as the `message` parameter.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000006`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * See below for the method-dependent base cost, plus 8 gas per 32 bytes of
     * context and message except digest.
     *
     * #### Signing algorithms
     *
     * - `0` (`Ed25519Oasis`): 1,500 gas, variable length context and message.
     * - `1` (`Ed25519Pure`): 1,500 gas, empty context, variable length message.
     * - `2` (`Ed25519PrehashedSha512`): 1,500 gas, pre-existing SHA-512 hash
     *   (64 bytes) as context, empty message.
     * - `3` (`Secp256k1Oasis`): 3,000 gas, variable length context and message
     * - `4` (`Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256`): 3,000 gas, pre-existing hash
     *   (32 bytes) as context, empty message.
     * - `5` (`Secp256k1PrehashedSha256`): 3,000 gas, pre-existing hash (32
     *   bytes) as context, empty message.
     * - `7` (`Secp256r1PrehashedSha256`): 9,000 gas, pre-existing hash (32
     *   bytes) as context, empty message.
     * - `8` (`Secp384r1PrehashedSha384`): 43,200 gas, pre-existing hash (48
     *   bytes) as context, empty message.
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * // Example 1: Signing with Ed25519Pure
     * Sapphire.SigningAlg alg = Sapphire.SigningAlg.Ed25519Pure;
     * bytes memory pk;
     * bytes memory sk;
     * (pk, sk) = Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(alg, Sapphire.randomBytes(32, ""));
     * bytes memory signature = Sapphire.sign(alg, sk, "", "signed message");
     *
     * // Example 2: Signing with Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256
     * alg = Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256;
     * bytes memory message = "message to sign";
     * bytes memory digest = abi.encodePacked(keccak256(message));
     * signature = Sapphire.sign(alg, sk, digest, "");
     *
     * // Example 3: Signing with Sr25519 (Substrate compatibility)
     * alg = Sapphire.SigningAlg.Sr25519;
     * bytes memory message = "message to sign";
     * signature = Sapphire.sign(alg, sk, "substrate", message);
     * ```
     *
     * @param alg The signing algorithm to use.
     * @param secretKey The secret key to use for signing. The key must be valid
     * for use with the requested algorithm.
     * @param contextOrHash Domain-Separator Context, or precomputed hash bytes.
     * The format and meaning depends on the selected algorithm (see above).
     * @param message Message to sign, should be zero-length if precomputed hash
     * given.
     * @return signature The resulting signature.
     * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/confidential.rs :: call_sign
     */
    function sign(
        SigningAlg alg,
        bytes memory secretKey,
        bytes memory contextOrHash,
        bytes memory message
    ) internal view returns (bytes memory signature) {
        (bool success, bytes memory sig) = SIGN_DIGEST.staticcall(
            abi.encode(alg, secretKey, contextOrHash, message)
        );
        require(success, "sign: failed");
        return sig;
    }

    /**
     * @notice Verifies that the provided digest was signed using the
     * secret key corresponding to the provided public key and the specified
     * signing algorithm.
     *
     * The `contextOrHash` and `message` parameters behave the same way as in the
     * sign() function. Please refer to the [sign()](#sign) function documentation
     * for details on how these parameters should be used with each algorithm.
     *
     * #### Precompile address
     *
     * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000007`
     *
     * #### Gas cost
     *
     * The algorithm-specific base cost below, with an additional **8 gas per
     * 32 bytes** of `context` and `message` for the `Ed25519Oasis`,
     * `Ed25519Pure` and `Secp256k1Oasis` algorithms.
     *
     * - `0` (`Ed25519Oasis`): 2,000 gas
     * - `1` (`Ed25519Pure`): 2,000 gas
     * - `2` (`Ed25519PrehashedSha512`): 2,000 gas
     * - `3` (`Secp256k1Oasis`): 3,000 gas
     * - `4` (`Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256`): 3,000 gas
     * - `5` (`Secp256k1PrehashedSha256`): 3,000 gas
     * - `7` (`Secp256r1PrehashedSha256`): 7,900 gas
     * - `8` (`Secp384r1PrehashedSha384`): 37,920 gas
     *
     * #### Example
     *
     * ```solidity
     * // Example 1: Verifying with Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256
     * Sapphire.SigningAlg alg = Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1PrehashedKeccak256;
     * bytes memory pk;
     * bytes memory sk;
     * bytes memory message = "message to sign";
     * // Create the hash
     * bytes memory digest = abi.encodePacked(keccak256(message));
     * // Generate keys and sign
     * (pk, sk) = Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(alg, Sapphire.randomBytes(32, ""));
     * bytes memory signature = Sapphire.sign(alg, sk, digest, "");
     * // Verify the signature (pass the same hash used for signing)
     * bool isValid = Sapphire.verify(alg, pk, digest, "", signature);
     * require(isValid, "Invalid signature");
     *
     * // Example 2: Verifying with Sr25519 (Substrate compatibility)
     * alg = Sapphire.SigningAlg.Sr25519;
     * message = "message to sign";
     * // Sign with "substrate" context
     * signature = Sapphire.sign(alg, sk, "substrate", message);
     * // Verify with the same "substrate" context
     * isValid = Sapphire.verify(alg, pk, "substrate", message, signature);
     * require(isValid, "Invalid signature");
     * ```
     *
     * @param alg The signing algorithm by which the signature was generated.
     * @param publicKey The public key against which to check the signature.
     * @param contextOrHash Domain-Separator Context, or precomputed hash bytes.
     * The format and meaning depends on the selected algorithm (see above).
     * @param message The message that was signed, should be zero-length if
     * precomputed hash was given in contextOrHash.
     * @param signature The signature to verify.
     * @return verified Whether the signature is valid for the given parameters.
     * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/confidential.rs :: call_verify
     */
    function verify(
        SigningAlg alg,
        bytes memory publicKey,
        bytes memory contextOrHash,
        bytes memory message,
        bytes memory signature
    ) internal view returns (bool verified) {
        (bool success, bytes memory v) = VERIFY_DIGEST.staticcall(
            abi.encode(alg, publicKey, contextOrHash, message, signature)
        );
        require(success, "verify: failed");
        return abi.decode(v, (bool));
    }

    /**
     * @notice Set the current transactions gas usage to a specific amount
     * @dev Will cause a reversion if the current usage is more than the amount.
     * @param toAmount Gas usage will be set to this amount
     * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/gas.rs :: call_pad_gas
     *
     */
    function padGas(uint128 toAmount) internal view {
        (bool success, ) = PAD_GAS.staticcall(abi.encode(toAmount));
        require(success, "verify: failed");
    }

    /**
     * @notice Returns the amount of gas currently used by the transaction
     * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/gas.rs :: call_gas_used
     */
    function gasUsed() internal view returns (uint64) {
        (bool success, bytes memory v) = GAS_USED.staticcall("");
        require(success, "gasused: failed");
        return abi.decode(v, (uint64));
    }
}

/**
 * @notice Hash the input data with SHA-512/256, according to
 * [NIST.FIPS.180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf).
 *
 * #### Precompile address
 *
 * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000102`
 *
 * #### Gas cost
 *
 * 115 gas, then 13 gas per word
 *
 * #### Example
 *
 * ```solidity
 * bytes32 result = sha512_256(abi.encodePacked("input data"));
 * ```
 *
 * #### Warning: SHA-512 vs SHA-512/256 Length-Extension Attacks
 *
 * [SHA-512](function.sha512.md#sha512) is vulnerable to [length-extension
 * attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Length_extension_attack), which are
 * relevant if you are computing the hash of a secret message. The
 * [SHA-512/256](function.sha512_256.md#sha512_256) variant is **not**
 * vulnerable to length-extension attacks.
 *
 * @param input Bytes to hash.
 * @return result 32 byte digest.
 * @custom:standard https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf
 * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/sha2.rs :: call_sha512_256
 */
function sha512_256(bytes memory input) view returns (bytes32 result) {
    (bool success, bytes memory output) = Sapphire.SHA512_256.staticcall(input);

    require(success, "sha512_256");

    return bytes32(output);
}

/**
 * @notice Hash the input data with SHA-512, according to
 * [NIST.FIPS.180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf)
 *
 * #### Precompile address
 *
 * `0x0100000000000000000000000000000000000101`
 *
 * #### Warning: SHA-512 vs SHA-512/256 Length-Extension Attacks
 *
 * [SHA-512](function.sha512.md#sha512) is vulnerable to [length-extension
 * attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Length_extension_attack), which are
 * relevant if you are computing the hash of a secret message. The
 * [SHA-512/256](function.sha512_256.md#sha512_256) variant is **not**
 * vulnerable to length-extension attacks.
 *
 * #### Gas Cost
 *
 * 115 gas, then 13 gas per word
 *
 * #### Example
 *
 * ```solidity
 * bytes memory result = sha512(abi.encodePacked("input data"));
 * ```
 *
 * @param input Bytes to hash.
 * @return output 64 byte digest.
 * @custom:standard https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf
 * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/sha2.rs :: call_sha512
 */
function sha512(bytes memory input) view returns (bytes memory output) {
    bool success;

    (success, output) = Sapphire.SHA512.staticcall(input);

    require(success, "sha512");
}

/**
 * @notice Hash the input data with SHA-384.
 * @param input Bytes to hash.
 * @return output 48 byte digest.
 * @custom:standard https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf
 * @custom:see @oasisprotocol/oasis-sdk :: precompile/sha2.rs :: call_sha384
 */
function sha384(bytes memory input) view returns (bytes memory output) {
    bool success;

    (success, output) = Sapphire.SHA384.staticcall(input);

    require(success, "sha384");
}

Design an implementation plan for adding encumbered wallets (deposit addresses) to the FDC trusted relayer PoC, following the FlexVaults pattern but simplified for a PoC.

## Current State

The current FdcAccounting.sol (at fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol) is a simple contract:
- `authorizedRelayer` (immutable address)
- `balances` mapping (private)
- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

The current accounting-demo.ts flow:
- Step 0: Send ETH to self on Sepolia
- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

Hardhat config uses solidity 0.8.24 with @oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat plugin.

## FlexVaults Pattern (what we want to mimic, simplified)

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain
4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

## Current State

The current FdcAccounting.sol (at fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol) is a simple contract:
- `authorizedRelayer` (immutable address)
- `balances` mapping (private)
- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

The current accounting-demo.ts flow:
- Step 0: Send ETH to self on Sepolia
- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain

   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

Design an implementation plan for adding encumbered wallets (deposit addresses) to the FDC trusted relayer PoC, following the FlexVaults pattern but simplified for a PoC.

## Current State

The current FdcAccounting.sol (at fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol) is a simple contract:
- `authorizedRelayer` (immutable address)
- `balances` mapping (private)
- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

The current accounting-demo.ts flow:
- Step 0: Send ETH to self on Sepolia
- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

Hardhat config uses solidity 0.8.24 with @oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat plugin.

## FlexVaults Pattern (what we want to mimic, simplified)

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain
4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

data.prompt:
Design an implementation plan for adding encumbered wallets (deposit addresses) to the FDC trusted relayer PoC, following the FlexVaults pattern but simplified for a PoC.

## Current State

The current FdcAccounting.sol (at fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol) is a simple contract:
- `authorizedRelayer` (immutable address)
- `balances` mapping (private)
- `processedTxHashes` mapping (private)
- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` - relayer-only
- `getBalance()` - caller's balance
- `getBalanceOf(user)` - relayer-only

The current accounting-demo.ts flow:
- Step 0: Send ETH to self on Sepolia
- Step 1: Deploy FdcAccounting on Sapphire
- Step 2-4: FDC attestation (prepare, submit, wait for proof)
- Step 5: Verify proof on Coston2
- Step 6: Call creditDeposit on Sapphire, query balance

Hardhat config uses solidity 0.8.24 with @oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat plugin.

## FlexVaults Pattern (what we want to mimic, simplified)

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain
4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

Hardhat config uses solidity 0.8.24 with @oasisprotocol/sapphire-hardhat plugin.

## FlexVaults Pattern (what we want to mimic, simplified)

FlexVaults creates an encumbered wallet like this:
1. At deploy time, the contract generates a secp256k1 keypair using Sapphire's `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` precompile
2. The private key is stored in Sapphire confidential storage (private bytes)
3. The derived Ethereum address is the "deposit address" ‚Äî users send ETH there on any EVM chain
4. For withdrawals, the contract uses `EIP155Signer` precompile to sign a raw EVM transaction from the encumbered wallet, and the backend broadcasts it to the destination chain

Key Sapphire precompiles needed:
- `Sapphire.generateSigningKeyPair(Sapphire.SigningAlg.Secp256k1, "")` ‚Äî generates keypair
- `EthereumUtils.k256DeriveAddress(publicKey)` ‚Äî derives address from public key  
- Or `EthereumUtils.generateKeypair()` which returns both
- For signing withdrawals: `EIP155Signer.sign(addr, secretKey, txFields)` ‚Äî signs a raw EVM transaction

These come from the `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` Solidity package.

## Requirements

1. **Contract changes (FdcAccounting.sol):**
   - At deployment: generate a keypair, store private key in confidential storage, derive deposit address
   - Expose `getDepositAddress()` public view ‚Äî returns the deposit address
   - `creditDeposit` should validate that the deposit was sent TO the deposit address (receivingAddress check)
   - Add `signWithdrawal(address user, uint256 amount, uint256 gasPrice, uint64 nonce, uint64 chainId)` ‚Äî relayer-only function that:
     - Debits user's balance
     - Signs a raw EVM tx sending `amount` from the encumbered wallet to `user`
     - Returns the signed raw transaction bytes
   - Need to import `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` for Sapphire precompiles

2. **Demo flow changes (accounting-demo.ts):**
   - Step 0 changes: Instead of sending ETH to self, send ETH to the deposit address
     - But we need the deposit address first, so deploy contract first
     - New order: Deploy ‚Üí get deposit address ‚Üí send Sepolia deposit to deposit address ‚Üí attest ‚Üí verify ‚Üí credit ‚Üí withdraw
   - Add Step 7: Withdrawal
     - Call `signWithdrawal()` on the contract to get signed raw tx
     - Broadcast the signed tx to Sepolia
     - Wait for confirmation
     - Log final balance (should be 0 after full withdrawal)

3. **Hardhat changes:**
   - Add `@oasisprotocol/sapphire-contracts` to contracts/package.json

## Design Constraints
- Keep it PoC-level ‚Äî no EIP-712 signatures, no pending withdrawal queue
- Single deposit address for all users (same as FlexVaults)
- The demo should be fully self-contained and work end-to-end
- Maintain existing code style (camelCase, async/await, descriptive errors)
- Solidity 0.8.24

## Questions to Address
1. What's the exact import path for Sapphire precompiles in Solidity?
2. How does EIP155Signer work ‚Äî what struct/fields does it need?
3. Should we validate receivingAddress in creditDeposit, or keep it simple?
4. For the withdrawal gas, who pays? The encumbered wallet needs Sepolia ETH for gas. In the PoC, the deposit itself provides the ETH.

Please provide a detailed implementation plan with specific code changes needed for each file.

content.content:
1‚Üí# FDC Trusted Relayer ‚Äî Sapphire Accounting
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíCross-chain deposit accounting on Oasis Sapphire using Flare Data Connector (FDC) attestations. Verifies Ethereum Sepolia transactions via FDC Merkle proofs, then credits deposits to a confidential Sapphire smart contract.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## How it works
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí1. **Sepolia deposit** ‚Äî Sends a small ETH transfer on Sepolia (the "deposit" to attest)
     8‚Üí2. **FDC attestation** ‚Äî Submits an attestation request to FdcHub on Coston2 and waits for the voting round to finalize
     9‚Üí3. **On-chain verification** ‚Äî Verifies the Merkle proof against Flare's consensus root via `FdcVerification`
    10‚Üí4. **Sapphire relay** ‚Äî Calls `creditDeposit()` on the `FdcAccounting` contract deployed on Sapphire testnet
    11‚Üí5. **Balance query** ‚Äî Reads the depositor's private balance from Sapphire confidential storage
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## Prerequisites
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí- Node.js and npm
    16‚Üí- A private key funded on three testnets (or separate keys per chain):
    17‚Üí  - **Sepolia** ‚Äî for the deposit tx ([faucet](https://sepoliafaucet.com/))
    18‚Üí  - **Coston2** ‚Äî for FDC attestation fees ([faucet](https://faucet.flare.network/coston2))
    19‚Üí  - **Sapphire testnet** ‚Äî for contract deployment + relay tx ([faucet](https://faucet.oasis.io/))
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí## Setup
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí```bash
    24‚Üí# Install root dependencies (from repo root)
    25‚Üínpm install
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí# Install Hardhat dependencies
    28‚Üícd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npm install && cd ../..
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí# Compile the Solidity contract
    31‚Üícd fdc-trusted-relayer/contracts && npx hardhat compile && cd ../..
    32‚Üí```
    33‚Üí
    34‚ÜíAdd to `.env` (in repo root):
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí```
    37‚ÜíCOSTON2_PK=0x...
    38‚Üí# Optional: defaults to COSTON2_PK if not set
    39‚Üí# SEPOLIA_PK=0x...
    40‚Üí# SAPPHIRE_PK=0x...
    41‚Üí```
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí## Run
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí```bash
    46‚Üínpm run accounting-demo
    47‚Üí```
    48‚Üí
    49‚ÜíThe demo is fully self-contained ‚Äî it sends its own Sepolia tx, attests it, and relays the deposit. Takes ~2-3 minutes (mostly waiting for the FDC voting round).
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí## Contract
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí`contracts/src/FdcAccounting.sol` ‚Äî deployed on Sapphire with:
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí- `creditDeposit(txHash, depositor, value)` ‚Äî relayer-only, with double-credit and zero-value protection
    56‚Üí- `getBalance()` ‚Äî depositor queries own balance (private storage)
    57‚Üí- `getBalanceOf(user)` ‚Äî relayer queries any user's balance
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí## Configuration
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí| Variable | Required | Default | Description |
    62‚Üí|---|---|---|---|
    63‚Üí| `COSTON2_PK` | Yes | ‚Äî | Private key for Coston2 (FDC attestation) |
    64‚Üí| `SEPOLIA_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sepolia (deposit tx) |
    65‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_PK` | No | `COSTON2_PK` | Private key for Sapphire (deploy + relay) |
    66‚Üí| `SEPOLIA_RPC` | No | `https://ethereum-sepolia-rpc.publicnode.com` | Sepolia RPC endpoint |
    67‚Üí| `SAPPHIRE_RPC` | No | `https://testnet.sapphire.oasis.io` | Sapphire RPC endpoint |
    68‚Üí| `DEPOSIT_AMOUNT` | No | `0.0001` | ETH amount for the Sepolia deposit |
    69‚Üí| `ACCOUNTING_CONTRACT_ADDRESS` | No | ‚Äî | Reuse an existing contract (skips deploy) |
    70‚Üí
